loans.name: Berta Alicia

texts.es: Berta Alicia G. de 58 años de edad, reside en Tacuba, ubicado en el departamento de Ahuachapán. Ella posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos de primera necesidad tanto alimenticios como para el hogar, Berta es una señora muy alegre y amable, quien debe esforzarse mucho por salir adelante y poder contar con todo lo necesario para tener una vida digna, ya que ella vive sola y su negocio es la única fuente de ingresos con la que ella cuenta. Desde hace 30 años que ella posee la tienda en su casa de habitación, por lo que es muy conocida en la zona y a pesar de que tiene mucha competencia en los alrededores, siempre es preferida por las personas del lugar, ya que es de mucha confianza en toda la zona. Berta solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar todo lo necesario para surtir más su negocio, comprando granos básicos, detergentes, desinfectantes, pan, leche, huevos, productos lácteos y todo lo que es más necesario y que sus clientes solicitan más en la tienda, así mismo Berta desea poder incluir productos nuevos, los cuales a pesar que tienen poco tiempo de estar en el mercado poseen una gran demanda como golosinas y bebidas, las cuales le asegurarían aumentar sus ventas, lo cual es la prioridad principal de ella, ya que de esta manera podrá contar con una mejor estabilidad en su hogar.
texts.en:
Berta Alicia G. is 58 years old. She lives in Tacuba, which is in the Ahuachapán department. She has a store where she sells basic needs products. She sells things like food and household products. Beta is a very happy and friendly woman. She puts forth a lot of effort to get ahead and to be able to have the necessities to live a decent life. She lives alone, and her business is her only source of income that she can count on. For 30 years she has had a store in her house. It is well known in the area. In spite of having a lot of competition around her, the people in her area always prefer her. She is very trusted in the whole area. Berta is requesting a loan to be able to buy everything she needs to better stock her business. She will buy basic grains, detergents, disinfectants, bread, milk, eggs, dairy products, and whatever else is most needed and most requested in the store. Berta also wishes to be able to include new products. Even though they have not been on the market long, there is a great demand for things like sweets and drinks. They will ensure an increase in her sales. That is her main priority. That way she will be able to count on better stability in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic needs products

loans.name: Abelia Concepción

texts.es: Abelia Concepción M. D. R. D. 52 años D. edad, es una madre D. familia muy trabajadora y entregada a su familia, la cual se gana la vida vendiendo diferentes tipos D. fruta, es gracias a este negocio como ella ha logrado darles todo lo necesario a sus tres hijos, dos D. 14 años D. edad, los cuales son gemelos y uno D. 13 años D. edad, los cuales dependen por completo D. Abelia, junto a ellos resiD. en Tonacatequepe, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador, lugar en el cual ha vivido durante 10 años. Abelia se dedica cada día a pelar, lavar y colocar la fruta en pequeñas bolsitas, muchas D. estas frutas son preparadas con limón, chile y sal, y debido a que coloca su venta en calle principal, cuenta con varios clientes, ya sean vecinos, personas que se encuentran D. paso o niños y jóvenes estudiantes D. una escuela que sen encuentra en el lugar. Abelia solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en su negocio, comprando más fruta, así mismo para poder comprar un pequeño terreno en Izalco ubicado en el departamento D. Sonsonate lugar D. nacimiento D. Abelia, esto lo hace con el deseo D. contar con un hogar propio y D. esta forma brindarle un techo seguro a sus tres hijos en el cual puedan sentirse seguros y confiados.
texts.en:
52-year old Abelia Concepción M. D. R. is a hardworking, devoted mother. She earns her living by selling fruit, and it is due to this business that she has managed to proviD. all the necessities for her three children. She has 14-year old twins and a 13-year old son, all of whom are completely dependent on her. Abelia and her family live in Tonacatequepe in the department of San Salvador. She has lived there for ten years. Every day she peels, washes, and places the fruit in little bags. Much of the fruit is seasoned with lemon, chile, and salt. Her stall is on the main street. Abelia’s customers might be neighbours, passers-by, children, or students from the nearby school. She is asking for money to invest in her business: she plans to buy more fruit. She also wants to buy a small piece of land in Izalco in the department of Sonsonate where she was born. Her wish is to build a house of her own there and proviD. a good home for her three children, a place where they can feel safe and self-confident.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fruit and some land

loans.name: Cecilia Ruth

texts.es: Cecilia Ruth A. R. de 32 años de edad vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como comerciante, y junto a sus dos hijos de 9 y 7 años de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Cecilia posee una venta de cosméticos, accesorios para el cabello, ropa, medicinas naturales, toallas femeninas y artículos para envolver regalos, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado de San Juan Opico, en donde desde hace varios años que se dedica a este tipo de ventas. Ella es una persona muy amable, la cual ofrece todos sus productos a muy buenos precios, así mismo cuenta con una gran variedad de productos, lo que atrae mucho más la atención de las personas. Debido a que ella posee bastante competencia en el lugar, ansía poder sobresalir de las demás ventas, incrementando la cantidad de productos que posee, es por ello que solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar variedad de ganchos para el cabello, cosméticos, artículos para regalo diferentes estilos de ropa tanto para niños como para jóvenes y adultos, de esta misma forma ella desea incluir productos nuevos como zapatos, y ropa interior, de esta manera ella espera convertirse en la principal opción de todas las personas que visitan el mercado y así mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
32-year old Cecilia Ruth A. R. lives with her businessman husband and their two children aged 9 and 7 who attend school. Cecilia has a small store selling cosmetics, hair accessories, clothing, natural medicines, feminine hygiene products, and gift wrap. Her business has been located in the San Juan Opico market for several years now. Cecilia is a very friendly person and sells her products at very good prices. She also has a wide variety of merchandise, which attracts people’s attention. Because there is a lot of competition in the area, it is important that her stall stands out from the rest, so she wishes to increase the range of products she sells. Cecilia is asking for a loan so she can buy hair accessories, cosmetics, giftware, clothing for children, teenagers, and adults, as well as new products such as shoes and underwear. By making these changes, she hopes to become the first port of call for everyone visiting the market and in this way increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, hair accessories, and giftware

location.town: San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran is a citizen of the city called Riwind, Pakistan which is about 30km far away from the city of Lahore. Her husband's name is A. M.. He is a vegetable seller by profession. She is a mother of two sons: her elder son runs a dairy business to financially support the family while the younger son is seven years old. The younger son cannot  go to school yet, due to financial constraints. 

Bashiran begum is also a very hardworking lady. She not only manages the household activities but also has a domestic sewing business. Her talent earns money for her family. Bashiran has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest in her son's business. He will buy a buffalo to improve his milk-selling business. Bashiran begum is hopeful that this investment will increase her sons’ income so that she will be able to send her youngest son to school soon.

loans.use: To purchase another buffalo for dairy business.

loans.name: Marta Alicia

texts.es: Marta Alicia Z. C. de 44 años de edad, es una señora muy alegre y trabajadora, la cual se dedica a la venta de calzado para dama, tenis y sandalias, desde hace más de 20 años que realiza este tipo de trabajo, obteniendo gran experiencia y así mismo muchos clientes. Ella vive junto a sus tres hijos y una nieta en Chalchuapa, departamento de Santa Ana. Marta trabaja para poder sostener a sus dos hijos menores ya que el mayor se dedica a trabajar para sostenerse el mismo y a su pequeño hijo. Marta posee su negocio en la calle principal del centro de Chalchuapa, un lugar el cual cuenta con mucho comercio y gran afluencia de personas. Ella ofrece muy buenos precios por lo que cuenta con muy buenas ventas diarias y así mismo posee clientes frecuentes. Marta solicita un préstamo a través del cual cuente con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de calzado, en variedad de estilos y colores  así mismo en diferentes tallas, de manera que pueda abarcar a mayor cantidad de personas y sus ventas puedan aumentar. Marta desea ampliar su negocio y de esta forma percibir mayores ganancias las cuales mejoren la estabilidad económica de su hogar.
texts.en:
Marta Alicia Z. C. is a happy and hard-working forty-four year old, who makes a living selling woman's shoes (tennis, sandals). She has been working in this field for twenty years gaining experience and earning many customers. She lives in Chalchuapa, in the department of Santa Ana, with her three children and granddaughter. Marta works so she can support her two youngest kids since the eldest works and supports himself and his small son. Marta's business is on Chalchuapa's main street, a busy commercial street with many affluent people. She offers good prices which is why she makes many sales each day and has regular customers. Marta is taking out a loan so she can buy more shoes of various styles, colors, and sizes so she can reach more people and increase her sales. Marta would like to increase her business and in this way earn more which will contribute to economic stability in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of shoes.

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Zahida is very supportive of her family. She always takes steps to give them comfort. She has given birth to five children, and all of them (except the youngest one) are getting an education.

Zahida sells clothes to financially support her family. She purchases clothes from the city of Faisalabad, famous for its textiles, and sells to her neighborhood clients. Her husband's name is Rasheed A.. He is a loader by profession. He loads everything from fruits and vegetables to construction supplies and delivers to the designated places. To deliver the items, he used his own donkey cart. He earns income on a daily business which helps manage the household expenses.

Zahida has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest in her husband’s business. He will buy a new donkey cart with the money, because the old cart has become rotted in different areas which gives him trouble loading items. Zahida is hoping that this investment will help her husband work better and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase a new donkey cart for a loading business

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en:
Aisha has two children but neither of them is able to attend school due to their poor financial condition.
 
She lives with her husband and family in Raiwind where her husband works in a factory.  His income is not sufficient to bear the financial cost of the family, so Aisha has started to prepare embroidered clothes by taking a loan from Asasah.  This earned her a good income.

Now she has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah to further expand her business. With the loan amount, she will buy material such as clothes, beads, colored thread and sketches in bulk to bring in more orders from her clients and to fulfill the current orders on time. 

Aisha hopes that she will be able to increase her profit and soon her children will start to go to school.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery material for embroidery business

loans.name: Yameena's Group

texts.en:
Yameena H. is a resident of Raiwind which is located near Lahore, Pakistan.  Her family consists of four members: Yameena, her husband and two children. Both of her children are getting their education. Her husband works in the government sector while she operates a beauty salon to financially support her family. 

She started this business last year by taking a loan from Asasah. Her business is doing well because of her hard work and dedication. She has been able to practice her art among her customers. 

Now she has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her beauty salon. She will buy beauty items such as creams, cosmetics and a hair dryer machine to better assist her customers.

Note: Yameena group member Samina is showing decoration pieces from her business and Munawar is showing items from her embroidery business in this photo.

loans.use: Purchase beauty items for beauty salon

loans.name: Jay Dawn

texts.en: Jay Dawn P. is from Oroquitea City. She is 26 years old and single. To make a living, Jay Dawn owns and operates a business providing motor transport services like "habal-habal" (a motorcycle with an extended seat that carries 2-6 passengers). Jay Dawn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2007, Jay Dawn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jay Dawn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jay Dawn is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Jay Dawn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Margie

texts.en: Margie C.'s main source of income comes from making and selling "cue" such as barbecue, chicken feet, hotdogs and chicken intestine in the market. She is 40 years old, married and has one school-age child. They are from the village of Pobalcion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Margie has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Margie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Margie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 24,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 24,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her seventh loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand and make some changes in his business

loans.name: Janetha

texts.en: Janetha V.'s main source of income comes from selling fish like bangus, pirit, sigarilyo, malansi and etch in her community. She is 44 years old, widowed and has five grown-up children. She is from the city of Bañaderos, Ozamiz City. Janetha has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Janetha joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Janetha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian B., 38 years old, is from the village of Rizal Lopez Jeana Misamis Occidental. Vivian is married and has two infant-aged children. Vivian owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Vivian joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Vivian from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra is the wife of M. R. and lives in Riwind with her family. Her husband works as a gardener. She is the mother of five sons. Three of her children are attending school while the other two do their jobs to financially support the family.  

Bushra is a very talented lady who operates her embroidery business to supplement the income of her family. She receives orders from her neighborhood clients and fulfills them on time. She started this business by receiving a loan from Asasah last years.

 Now she has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah to invest in her new dairy business. Since a young age she helped her father in his dairy business and take care of his buffalos. Her experience inspired her to start this work independently because she has an interest in it. She is hopeful that this will help her to increase more income for her family. She will buy a buffalo with the loan amount in order to change her current business into the dairy business.

Bushra is showing her current business in this photo.

loans.use: Purchase a buffalo to start a dairy business

loans.name: Rammynel

texts.en:
Rammynel O., 29 years old, is from the village of Consuelo, Magsaysay Misamis Oriental. Rammynel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rammynel owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a  retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily used products in the local community. Rammynel has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rammynel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rammynel is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rammynel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites S. is from the village of  Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Marites is married and has 3 adult children. Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa D. is from the village of Northern Pob. Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Elsa is widowed and has 5 adult children. Elsa owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elsa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy V. is from the village of  Consuelo, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Nancy is married and has 3 school-aged children. Nancy owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. Nancy has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Nancy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Duong

texts.en: Shown in the photo is Mrs. Duong R., who lives in Siem Reap Province. Duong R., age 34, sells various kinds of vegetables in Psa Kroam Market, and earns approximately $3 profit a day. Besides her current work, she also raises a few poultry at her home for extra income. She has a life partner in her husband who shares financial responsibility for his family by driving a motor taxi. He runs his business very well because he has skills in communication which he uses with his customers. However, his income is declining due to the fact that his motorcycle breaks down frequently. That is why Duong R. has decided to ask for a loan of $1,200 to replace the broken motorcycle. She achieves to use the remaining money from the loan to accrue financial capital for her vegetable business.

loans.use: To replace the broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Maqsooda's Group

texts.en:
Maqsooda lives in a small city called Riwind which is about 30km from Lahore, Pakistan. She lives there with her family. Her husband's name is K. A.. He works in the field and also sells milk. 


Maqsooda is a very talented lady. She not only manages the household chores but also handles her business of making artificial flowers for sale. She does this work to generate income for her family.  


She has eight children: seven sons and a daughter. Four of them couldn’t get an education and they had to work to financially support the family, but Maqsooda has managed to provide education facilities for her younger children.  



Maqsooda has applied for a loan for the fifth time from Asasah. With this loan, she will buy another buffalo to expand her husband’s milk selling business.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann T. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old. Mary Ann is single. Mary Ann owns & operates a general store shere she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month..

In 2010, Mary Ann joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Mary Ann from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Amada

texts.en:
Amada G. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 56 years old. Amada is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Amada owns & operates a business selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Amada has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Amada joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Amada has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Amada is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make the products that she has for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Amada from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Kav's Group

texts.en:
The four people shown in the photograph are low-income people who are jointly requesting a loan. They are all living in Siem Reap Province, in Cambodia. One of these people, Mr. Kav C., age 41, has been selected to be leader by the other group members. Kav C. and his wife currently have a fishing business in and around the Tunle Sap River. This couple has been fishing in the river for more than ten years and they earn an average of $6 per day. This allows them to support their three school-aged children, including school fees. Due to the coming rising water and fishing season, the river is full of fish. Kav C., however, is lacking equipment to fish and that is why he requested a loan. With the funds, he will purchase nets, traps, and other tools for his fishing activities.

There are three other borrowers in this group who have requested a loan as follows:
Mr. L. will be using his first loan to better support his fishing business.
Mr. S. makes a living by fishing and is asking for a loan to buy more nets and traps fish better.
Mrs. S. is a grocery seller, asking for a loan to sustain her business growth.

loans.use: To purchase nets, traps, and other tools for his fishing activities.

loans.name: Belencita

texts.en:
Belencita S. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 48 years old. Belencita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Belencita owns & operates a business making & selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Belencita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Belencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Belencita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make the products that she has for sale. Belencita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Belencita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Chong

texts.en: Chong C., 50, is a local fisherman who has been engaged in the fishing business for more than twenty years. He is skillful in his business. He always goes fishing in and around the Tunle Sap River, where the fish shelter. He brings his fish to the local market for his wife to sell retail. Chong C. has four children who are single and are no longer in school. To help meet the family's expenses a little better, three of his children are employed (two are fishermen and one works in the construction field). Chong C. is taking out his loan to purchase a secondhand motor to provide transportation for the family and to buy extra fishing equipment to support his business during the approaching fishing season.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motor and to buy extra fishing equipment.

loans.name: Razia Begum's Group

texts.en:
Razia begum is very supportive to her family. Previously, she took a loan from Asasah. Her husband started a grocery shop by using the loan amount. Now she has applied again for a loan because she wants to expand his business by putting more grocery items in his shop. 

Razia is a seamstress by profession. She sews clothes for neighborhood clients and for her relatives as well. She receives reasonable charges from them. Her earnings help her to share the financial burden with her husband. She lives in a city called Riwind, in Pakistan with her husband and five children: two daughters and three sons. Three of the children are attending school while the other two help their family financially by doing jobs in the factory. The children couldn’t get an education due to poor financial conditions. Razia begum is hopeful that her husband will be able to increase his income and help his family to live better standard of life.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for grocery shop.

loans.name: Moth

texts.en: Moth L., 37, is a low-income person living in Siem Reap Province. She is a good and determined single mother who tries to feed her five children, even though she is recently divorced from her husband. She has one married child who lives separately, while the remainder are staying in the family home and working in a variety of jobs. Moth L. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, Moth L. goes to a place where fishermen sell fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, which she sells them retail. Moth L. has a son who is not yet working. She hopes to encourage her son to have a job, but she has no cash to make that possible. So, she would request a loan to purchase a used motor-trailer taxi for her son to begin a service business.

loans.use: To purchase a use motor-trailer taxi for her son to begin a service business.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie L. is from the village of Bliss, Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years of age and married to Junicor L.. This couple has been blessed with 2 children: 1 is now at school age and the other one is still an infant.  Elvie is presently engage in operating a Sari-sari store where she also is dealing in cellphones and cell accessories. Aside from that, she is earning support from her husband who is a cellphone technician. Elvie has been engaged in this kind of business for 10 years already and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month from her Sari-sari store and cellphone, cell accessories dealing businesses.

In April 2007, Elvie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elvie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital for her Sari-sari store, cellphone and cell accessories dealing business. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Elvie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, savings for future use especially for future business expansion and her children’s education.
 
 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing Sari-sari store, cellphone and cell accessories dealing businesses.

loans.name: Chann

texts.en: Chann S. is a 26-year-old married father caring for two young kids. Both children are still living in the family home and are pupils in the local primary school. Chann is a recycling seller - he buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods he deals in are mostly leftover electricity wires and plastics. His wife assists him with his business activities. Chann is looking for a loan to use as capital to buy more stock to increase his profits.

loans.use: To buy more stock to increase his profits

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean N. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 25 years old. Jean is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jean owns & operates a business venture providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Jean has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jean is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia M. is from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting assorted crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling her own harvested crops in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 31 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Alicia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for rice production. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Alicia from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for rice production

loans.name: Alexis

texts.fr:
S. Alexis a 31 ans, née à Kamonyi dans l’ancien préfecture de Gitarama aujourd’hui se trouve dans la province du nord du Rwanda mais il habite pour le moment à Kigali. Il est jeune marié et n’a pas encore d’enfants car sa femme est enceinte. Il est Evangéliste de l’Eglise ADEPR (association des églises de pentecôte) de Kicukiro Shell son niveau d’étude est de 6 ème année primaire et quatre années de Théologie.
Cette évangélisation lui doit le salaire, grâce à ce salaire il épargne successivement.ces épargnes lui a permit de se marier et il construit une maison d’habitation, malgré son petit salaire.
Il vient de contracter un prêt avec ACB pour acheter le matériel de son petit secrétariat public qui est la photocopieuse. Dans le passé, il a soldé  quatre  prêts. Avec ses épargnes il veut arriver à monter une papeterie .Il souhaite aussi que une fois les bénéfices augmentent sa femme peut continuer à étudier car elle s’est arrêté en quatrième année secondaire.
texts.en:
Alexis S. is 31 years old; he was born in Kamonyi, formerlyin the Gitarama prefecture and now in the North province of Rwanda, but currently he lives in Kigali. He recently got married and has no children yet, but his wife is pregnant. He is an evangelist of the ADEPR (an association of Pentecostal churches) in Kucukiro Shell. He has six years of primary school studies and four years of theology studies. His work for the church assures him a salary, thanks to which he has been able to grow his savings little by little, making it possible for him to get married. Although his salary is small, he was able to have a house built to live in. He is taking out a loan from ACB in order to purchase supplies for his own public business center, namely a photocopier. In the past, he had four loans. With his savings, he would like to open a stationery store. He is also hoping that, once his income increases, his wife will be able to continue her studies as she did not go beyond the fourth year of study.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a photocopier for the stationery store

loans.name: Christian

texts.en:
Christian C. is from the village of Gingoog City. He is 40 years old. Christian is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Christian owns & operates a business venture providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Christian has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Christian joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Christian is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase the materials needed to provide hairdressing services. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Christian from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service.

loans.name: Dep

texts.en: Mrs. Dep E., 34, supports her family by selling fish paste. Also, she buys fresh fish and turns thE. into fish paste to sell. She is able to generate an average of $3 per day and has been engaged in this sector for years. Dep E.'s husband is also a financial earner. He is a porter in the local busy market. The couple has given birth to five kids who are all going to school. Dep E. is looking for a loan as capital to order a larger quantity of fresh fish to make into fish paste to sell.

loans.use: To order a larger quantity of fresh fish, with which to make fish paste to sell

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen A. is from the village of  North Poblacion, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Allen is married and has 2 school-aged children. Allen owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells herbal food supplements. Allen has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Allen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Allen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rossetti

texts.en:
N. Rossetti is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  She is hardworking and wants to succeed in life.  Rossetti has a retail shop in Kalisizo where she sells various retail goods and food.  She has had her business for six months.

To help expand her business, Rossetti is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock and to expand her inventory. Rossetti hopes to generate profit from her business to support herself in the future.


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to purchase stock

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: Chheng T., 26, owns a medium wooden house and a grocery shop where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets and soft drinks. She retails her inventory to people who are passers-by, as well as neighbors living near her house. She sometimes sells on credit and will collect the income a few days later. She has been running a grocery investment for a long time and earns an average of $3 a day. To ensure that her entire family has stability financial, her husband works in the construction sector. This couple now lives with a young child who is going to school. Chheng T. is taking out her loan to increase her inventory and to mend her old motor, which breaks often.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to mend her old motor

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
N. Immaculate is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Immaculate has a business selling bunches of bananas to the townspeople of Kalisizo.

To expand her business, Immaculate is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy 30 or more bunches of bananas, which she then hopes to sell in the market.  Immaculate hopes to generate profit from selling bananas to enable her to develop her business and sell other types of goods.


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more product (bananas) to resell

loans.name: Chup

texts.en: Mrs. Chup P., 22, is a young woman and the mother of a young child who is not enrolled in school. To earn a living, she owns a small store inside a market, which is a good location to raise income. In her shop, she sells different kinds of items such as soft drinks, sweets, plastic goods, and cooking ingredients. To help be responsible for their family, her husband is an internal staff member of an entertainment club. Chup P. currently is selling well because she is skilled at communicating with the public. To meet the needs of her family, she is applying for a loan to use as capital to accumulate a bigger quantity of various inventory items to sell.

loans.use: To accumulate a bigger quantity of various inventory items to sell

loans.name: Angele

texts.en:
Angele was born in 1961. She is married with four children. Angele has been a businesswoman for a long time because she has almost 18 years of experience in her business. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 2 in the evening.

Now, Angele is requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business of selling foodstuffs, especially cassava leaves and so on. This loan will help her to satisfy the demands of her customers, which will allow her to earn more profit.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana A. is from the village of  Talon, Gingoog City. She is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Susana owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. Susana has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Susana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Susana is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Susana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a married woman with three children who all attend school. Her husband is a primary school teacher and he contributes to the family's basic needs. She has been operating her retail shop for the past ten years and sells to the entire local community. She also runs a video show and cultivates plants as other sources of income. 


With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase stock (two 50kg sacks of sugar, rice and cooking flour); to purchase bulbs, wiring cables and sockets; and to pay a deposit of Kshs 35,000 to the Kenya power and lighting company.


Maria's major challenge is seasonality. In particular, sales are low during the months of January and February. She hopes to have a wholesale business in the future and to increase profits. She decided to join Yehu to get a loan for her business operations. She cited food as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her store and other items for her video business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet Y. is from the town of Guitas. She is 46 years old. Juliet is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juliet joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Juliet from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Loriza

texts.en:
Loriza L. thanks all those who supported her, allowing the development of her business. Loriza took out her previous loan of 25,000 PHP from Kiva  to purchase additional GreenLife products and to expand her natural medicine business. The loan enabled her to offer a wider assortment of goods to her customers which increased traffic to her stall and maintained customer loyalty to her products in the community. She has been pleased with how her investments are turning out and how her business is improving. Thank you so much for your kindness and generosity towards Loriza and her family. Loriza prays they all will be blessed. She has a sound and solid relationship with the Kiva/ASHI partnership.

Now, Loriza is proposing another Kiva loan to advance her growing business, which she has been able to improve due to her access to bigger loans from Kiva lenders.

Loriza also revealed the massive impact the loan has made on her family. With the additional income, she was able to afford to buy desired needs for her family and ensure prompt weekly payment of her obligation to ASHI. Loriza is also happy because she is able to support her husband in meeting the family's needs. The couple love what they do in making their business succeed. For her, it is joy to see fulfillment in her business and family and, with her children growing up, she wants to see them having a decent life someday.

Loriza is thankful to ASHI and Kiva lenders for their continuous support of her dreams. Her long term goals are to provide a sustainable life for her family and enable them to build their own comfortable house to live in.

loans.use: to advance and expand her natural medicine business

loans.name: Murod

texts.en:
M. Murod is 47 years old. He is married and has 5 children. Murod is very diligent and hard-working young man. With his own car, he is providing  taxi services. For the last 10 years the current business has been the main income for the family, allowing Murod to improve the living conditions of his large family. As with any business, Murod's business also requires some investment from time to time. Thus, now his car needs some fixing. For this purpose Murod requests 4700 Somoni. Murod promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all those supporting him.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Thorough fixing of the vehicle used for providing taxi services.

loans.name: Fasha Group

texts.fr:
Aline N. est une commerçante âgée de 24ans qui habite la Commune de Rugombo en Province Cibitoke  à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce du riz depuis cinq ans au Marché de Rugombo.Elle était cultivatrice avant de commencer cette activité commerciale. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 5e année du primaire. Elle est  divorcée. Elle est maintenant  au 3e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 2enfants âgés de 6ans et de 3ans dont un est à l’école. Elle a connu de sérieux problèmes du ménage parce que son mari le maltraitait, raison pour laquelle elle a été contrainte de divorcer. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour augmenter  la quantité de riz qu’elle achète pour revendre aux clients. Elle a l’espoir qu’avec le crédit de Turame, elle pourra avoir beaucoup de bénéfice et faire ses épargnes pour résoudre ses divers problèmes financiers et acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison.

Elle reconnait que le crédit Turame est facile à rembourser et affirme qu’elle va continuer à le prendre.

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Fasha ».
texts.en:
Aline N. is a 24 year old shopkeeper who lives in the town of Rugombo in the Cibitoke province located in western Burundi. For the past five years she has sold rice at the Rugombo market. She is divorced. She is currently involved in her third community loan with Turame. She is the mother of two children, aged 3 and 6 years of which one is in school. She has known serious household troubles because her husband mistreated her, which was the reason she was forced to divorce him. She is asking for a Kiva loan to increase to quantity of rice she buys and can resell to her clients. With the loan from Turame, she could increase her profits and invest in her savings to solve her varied financial issues and buy a plot of land on which to build her own house. She recognizes that the loan from Turame is easy to repay and she asserts that she will continue to borrow from them. She is a member of the Fasha Community group.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase the quantity of rice she buys to resell to her clients

loans.name: Nasim

texts.en:
H. Nasim is 37 years old. He is married and has 3 children. Nasim is running his own butcher shop. He has had a butcher shop and meat selling business for 12 years. He provides the markets with meat and his family with necessary food. Now, Nasim is requesting a loan of 6000 Somoni. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro entrepreneur and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan. Nasim is counting on your help. Your support will really help him. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.name: Naema

texts.en:
Naema A. is a 56-year-old housewife. Naema has two sons who are married and live in another village. Naema's husband suffers from health issues, so Naema is the one who works to support herself and her husband.

Naema started growing vegetables on a piece of land that her husband owns, and on which they have a greenhouse. Because summer has already started, and it's relatively hotter than in past years, she decided to build a tube well (a type of water well in which a long stainless steel pipe is bored into an underground aquifer) to avoid water shortages in the coming years.

In the picture, Naema appears at the FATEN office.

loans.use: Build a tube well

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy A. is from the village of  Talon Gingoog City. She is 22 years old. Juvy is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Juvy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Juvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Juvy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

To make a living, Mary Jean owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Mary Jean has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Besiga Mukama Development Group, Mubende

texts.en:
She is 35, enterprisingly ambitious, and a woman with a sense of purpose. She has, for the last ten years, exhibited these hallmarks in operating her retail shop in Mubende Town. She is the mother of three and she goes under the name of N. Justine. Her customers cut across all levels of society, from traders to the lowest common denominators in her locality.

Justine was a nurse before and she used the money she had saved to start this business. She describes herself as a trustworthy individual who customers can put their faith in. This, she says, is the reason why she has lasted this long.

With this loan, Justine says she wants to purchase in bulk retail items that she will resell. This, she says, will lay a good foundation for better profits in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like basins, cups, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Amegnon Kossi

texts.en:
Amegnon S. is 29 years old and has a business selling second-hand clothing. He has been working at this business since 2008. He is 29 years old and married to a woman who sells cloth and fabric. They have two children. 

Amegnon’s income helps him provide for his young family. He has requested a loan of 400,000 Communauté Financière Africaine Francs (CFA) to allow him to purchase more clothing to sell in his business, which is located in Lomé’s Grand Marché.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing for resale

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is happily married with six children; one still attends school while the others are adults. Her husband is a farmer and he contributes a lot to the family's basic needs. She operates a business of buying and selling goats to the general public and to the butcher shops. 

With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase 20 goats and be a wholesale supplier. Nadzua faces the challenge of transportation as she incurs high cost of transporting goats from the rural areas to the marketplace. In the future, she would like to expand her livestock goat business.

Nadzua decided to join Yehu (a Kiva partner) because of the good reputation of the organization and accessibility to sustainable financial services. She owns a home without electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is transport.

loans.use: To purchase 20 goats

loans.name: Lianlanie

texts.en: Lianlanie C. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Lianlanie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lianlanie runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for her business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Lianlanie has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Lianlanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lianlanie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lianlanie from HSPFI. loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mr. Ly S. is a middle-aged man living in a high wooden house located near the river. His wife sells some groceries for profit. This couple is blessed with two young children who are enrolled in the primary school. Ly S. is skillful at repairing fishing boats and currently uses his knowledge to earn an income. He is determined and hardworking at his job. Most of his customers appreciate him and believe that he is a good repairman in the village. Recently, Ly S. has been hired by people to mend their broken boats but he does not have enough essential material to carry out his repairs. Ly S. is humbly requesting a loan to buy the required articles.

loans.use: To buy essential material to carry out his boat repairs

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios A. is 55 years old and married with seven children, living in the town of Guitas. She has been involved in farming for more than eight years now and tills her land for planting rice crops that she sells at the market, earning about Php5000. She hopes to double her next harvest and is doing her best to keep the farm productive.

Remedios joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and pay the laborers who helped till her farm. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Remedios from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Abdulla

texts.en:
Abdulla J. is 42 years old and married with three children. For 29 years he has been running a business of beekeeping, which he originally started because he had difficulties finding employment. The collaborative effort of his family has been the key to his business' growth and he now has a steady customer base due to the quality of his products. Currently, Abdulla is seeking a loan of 5000 Somoni that he wishes to use to expand his business and allow him to offer better products. Abdulla and his family sincerely thanks you for your support in becoming a part of their achievements.

texts.en:
Johny lives in Bethlehem and owns a barber shop in the old city of Bethlehem. Johny has been working as barber for the last 27 years. Johny's shop needs a new front door and some improvements. He also wants to purchase new tools to keep up with modern trends in his profession.

Bethlehem city suffers from sudden curfews and hard conditions due to the occupation of Palestine, so Johny came to FATEN to take a $3,000 loan; money that he couldn't save because of the current situation.

In the photo, Johny is standing in his shop.

loans.use: Pay for a new front door

To feed his family, Mr. G. has a restaurant called Café-Bar-Resto-Shalom. He’s had the restaurant since 2007. He has requested a loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA to help him grow the restaurant by increasing the menu and capacity.

loans.use: To expand his restaurant

Since Ilhomidin started his store, he has been able to increase his clientele and provide them with good service. He is requesting a loan of 13,000 Somoni, which he will use to buy merchandise to increase his assortment. With your help, Ilhomidin will get ahead.

loans.name: Mweruphe

texts.en:
Mweruphe is a married woman with seven children,six of her children attend school and one is too young for school.She has been operating her business for the last five years of buying goats for rearing while they are still young and selling them after sometime at a profit.
Goat is important component in dry land farming system. Marginal or undulating lands unsuitable for other types of animals like cow or farming, goat is the best alternative.With very low investments goat rearing can be made into a profitable venture for small and marginal farmers.

She rears goats for milk and meat. Goat is a multi functional animal and plays a significant role in the economy and nutrition of landless, small and marginal farmers in the area.Goats can efficiently survive on available shrubs and trees in adverse harsh environment in low fertility lands where no other crop can be grown. 

The goats are normally taken out to the field in search of pastures very early in the morning at six o'clock,until noon they are returned back home.Mweruphe took us to the hut where she normally keeps the goats at night.Her spouse is a farmer and he helps in the running of the business and sells at the market place to her neighboring community.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase six goats. Previously she sold vegetables and paraffin to contribute to her other source of income.

Mweruphe faces the challenge of the high cost of transporting goats to the market place. She hopes to supply at wholesale someday. She owns a house with no electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To purchase six  livestock goats for rearing .

loans.name: Elise Patricia Anique

texts.fr:
Femme âgée de 46ans, vendeuse du poisson salé en détail depuis 8ans,mariée,mère de 5 enfants dont 3 vont à l'école.
Avant de vendre le poisson salé, elle vendait des friandises devant une école de son quartier et après elle s'est lancée dans le poisson salé.
Elle a sur son étalage differentes sortes de poissons salé: poisson sole, poisson thon, poisson morue, elle choisie les meilleurs pour équilibrer le prix et la qualité.
L'actuel prêt lui permettra d'agrandir son stock de marchandises, comme ses amies le font, elle veut aussi faire le séchage traditionnel avec du poisson vendu sur place pour agrandir son commerce.
pour ses  enfants, elle veut leurs assurer une bonne éducation et leurs construire une belle maison avec l' aide de son époux.ses proche la qualifie de femme sérieuse.
texts.en:
This woman is 46 years old and has sold salted fish at retail for 8 years. She is married and has 5 children, of whom 3 go to school. Before selling salted fish, she used to sell sweets in front of a school in her area. Afterward, she began selling salted fish. In her display of goods, she keeps different types of salted fish: sole, tuna, and cod, and she selects the best options to balance price and quality. This current loan will allow her to enlarge her stock of merchandise, as her friends have done, and she also wants to dry fish in the traditional way on the spot to enlarge her business. She wants to ensure a proper education for her children and build a nice house with the help of her husband. Her friends and family describe her as a serious woman.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of salted fish

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
Mohira, her husband and their three children live in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. With the prime goal of helping her husband with the family expenses, she started her clothing sales business four years ago. This business is a good match for her because she loves sales and is a proficient saleswoman. Throughout the years, Mohira has kept up her business with much effort and dedication. And through this business, she has been able to provide an education for her three children. In order to keep the business growing, she needs a loan of 3,500 Somoni to purchase seasonal clothing. It is important for Mohira and her family to have your support.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Cresilda

texts.en:
Cresilda E. is from the village of Taglimao, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 62 years old. Cresilda is married and has 2 school-aged children. Cresilda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. Cresilda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Cresilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Cresilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cresilda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
