loans.name: Habibulo

texts.en:
G. Habibulo is from the district of Dj.Rasulov, Tajikistan. Currently, he dedicates himself to his livestock business, a popular enterprise that is characteristic of the region. He is the father of 4 children who he cares for and has the responsibility of educating. It’s important to note that Habibulo is very conscious of his duty to support his family financially. For this reason, he turned to IMON International to obtain a loan to purchase some pregnant cows to help him increase his income. With your help, Habibulo will be able to make his business succeed and support his family. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Hapuyo Kamukamu Group, Mubende

texts.en:
Enterprising 48-year-old A. Richard has operated his alcohol-selling business for the last six years in Kirayabyenju, Mubende. He was first operating a tailoring business before he made a decision to start up this business.

This kind of business is highly profitable given the high consumption rates of alcohol in parts of western Uganda. In a week, Richard makes profits totalling 100,000 shillings. He is upbeat that his profits will increase once he can access this loan. With the self-belief he personifies, his future in this competitive business is bright.

Richard also ekes out profits from a tailoring business. With this loan, he wants to buy more crates of beer and other alcoholic drinks for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer and other alcoholic drinks to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 32 years old, single, and still lives with her parents. Lydia owns a small business selling various styles of clothes. This is the 8th year of successful operation of her business. The hours of her shop are from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Saturday. 

Lydia is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing various models of clothes. With this loan Lydia hopes to change her life by saving money for her future.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou G., 29, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Francisco G., a barber, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn an income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own barber shop where her husband works as head barber.

Marilou has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her barber shop.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying equipment and expanding her barber shop. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying equipment and expanding her barber shop

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert has been operating his vehicle repair and hardware shop for the past year. He is married with five children who all attend school. With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase new pedals, motorcycle tyres, rings and bicycle spokes for his shop. Gilbert’s other source of income is from his motorbike (boda boda) hire business. 


The major challenge in his business is seasonality. He hopes to expand his business by adding more stock to his hardware shop. Gilbert joined Yehu to get a loan to develop financially and improve his standard of living.


Gilbert owns a home with no electricity and no piped water. His greatest monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his hardware store.

loans.name: Kalungi Savings And Credit Group, Mubende

texts.en:
50-year-old K. Stella began her cattle-selling business three years ago in Lwensasi, Mubende. This unwaveringly determined married woman has been able to bring in profits on the strength of this business alone. In a week, she makes more than 50,000 shillings. She was, prior to the establishment of this business, a small boutique owner who sold clothes.

Stella has been able to give her seven children an education with profits from this business. She wants to use this loan to buy thoroughbred cows that she will later resell.

loans.use: To purchase thoroughbred cows for resale

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley K. is 31 years old and is married to Caroline Koros. He is the father of one child who is three years old.

Stanley K. practises horticultural farming in Chepsigot with the support of his wife. He has been in this business for four years and he is able to make a monthly income of Kshs 12,150.

This is his first loan with KADET. He plans to use the money from this loan to purchase a water tank, sprinklers and water pipes. He will also use part of the loan to hire someone to graft the mangoes he has planted on his farm. He anticipates making a profit which he will use to expand his business by getting into dairy farming.

Stanley hopes to be a leading horticulturalist in the region to the extent that he can start a demonstration plot, for use by the Ministry of Agriculture on field days, to educate other farmers.

loans.use: To purchase water tank and sprinklers for irrigation

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise was born in 1977, and she is a widow with two children, 7 and 9; both are in school. Marie Louise takes care of four dependents these days. She employs two people from her community as helpers so that her business runs well. The hours of her daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Marie Louise is now requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business which is very important for her and for her community because she will be able to satisfy her customers. Once this happens, Marie Louise will be able to earn more profit. With extra profits, she will save money for her children.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with six children who all go to school. Betty also takes care of additional family members. 


She owns a retail shop in Kisaasi where she sells all types of merchandise like sugar, soap, salt and cooking oil. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like bags of sugar, cooking oil and boxes of soap. She has been in this business for six years. 


As well as this retail business, Betty also gets some money from rental rooms. She rents her business premises at 50000/= per month. Her customers are the local community. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala city to her place of work in Kisaasi. 


Betty aspires to see her business grow and to start selling wholesale only. She decided to work with MCDT because it was easy to work with. 


Betty resides in and owns a four roomed house and her family has access to electricity and piped water. Her month expenses includes food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap and cartons of salt

Jeanne d'Arc now is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business, especially through purchasing more foodstuffs for her shop. This expansion will be important for her and her community because the community will be satisfied by her service. With the extra money, Marie expects to save for her family.

texts.en:
Elsa J., a widow at 54, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her child can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store and computer shop for the past few years.

Elsa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. To ensure the success of her business, Elsa would like to apply for a 16,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital to expand her business by buying computer parts needed for the shop. She will use half of the loan to purchase groceries, toiletries and beverages for the variety store. Elsa dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy computer parts, groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptiste is 33 years old, married with two children who are 2 and 5 years old.  Jean Baptiste is commonly known in the business of selling Irish potatoes and he has been in this business for about 2 years.  The hours of his business are from 6 am until 7 pm every day.

Jean Baptiste has realized that he is not presently able to satisfy the demand of his customers, so he wants to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Jean Baptiste will purchase a large quantity of Irish potatoes and he really hopes that the demand of his customers will totally be met.  Once this demand is totally met, Jean Baptiste will hopefully earn a lot of profit, more than previously, and this profit will be used for a further reinvestment in his business as well as saving for a better future.

loans.use: A large quantity of Irish potatoes

texts.en:

Formerly Sarah was dealing in charcoal, but changed her business to mobile phone accessories a few months ago.  She wants to use this loan to buy more mobile phone accessories like Sim packs, Airtime, chargers, and pay phones. She rents her business premises for 45,000 UGX per month. She works seven days a week and her customers are the people who live near her shop. Sarah‘s business challenges include thieves and defaulters. 

Sarah is hoping to build her own house and to own a fully stocked mobile phone shop.  She joined MCDT because they offer group co-guarantor-ships.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Abdou

texts.fr: Monsieur Abdou B. est un jeune commerçant  de 38 ans qui évolue  dans le secteur du commerce depuis plus de 20 ans déjà. Il est marie et membre de la caisse de Bambilor depuis janvier 2010. C’est un chef de famille qui a en charge 3 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 10 mois et 9 ans. Il s’active dans le commerce de bovin qui est une activité qu’il a hérité  de son père, un ancien paysan-éleveur. Monsieur B. sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs qui sera destine a l’achat de6 a 7 moutons. Par conséquent  ce crédit  lui permettra d’accroitre ses bénéfices qui lui permettent de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels ainsi que ceux de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdou B. is a young merchant aged 38 who has spent more than 20 years already in the business sector. He is married and has been a member of the Bambilor group fund since January 2010. He is the head of his household and is responsible for 3 children, whose ages vary from 10 months to 9 years old. He is active in the animal-rearing business, which he inherited from his father, a former rural livestock farmer. Mr. B. is seeking a loan of 100,000 frs, which will be used to buy 6 or 7 sheep. As a result, this loan will allow him to increase his profits, which will allow him to provide for himself and his family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his working capital

texts.en:
Tatyana is married with two adult children. She has a degree in economics. Tatyana is a small market vendor from Dneprorudnyi, where she owns a clothing business in one of the local markets. She owns a nice, spacious kiosk/store, which makes it very comfortable for her customers to try on different clothing items. Tatyana has been in this trade for over twelve years. Presently, she has 60,000 UAH worth of inventory; her gross income is about $3170 per month.

Tatyana is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment of inventory she offers for sale in her kiosk. She is planning to consistently develop her venture and see its further stable growth in the future.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of her inventory

loans.name: Abadacogora Group

texts.fr:
K. Edouard est âgée de 32 ans, il est jeune marié donc il n’a pas encore d’enfants. Edouard est président du  groupe appelle ABADACOGORA, ce groupe travail en commun pour l’expansion de leur business diversifié dont tous font le commerce, il travail six jours la semaine.Edouard lui est vendeur des produit alimentaires qui sont pomme de terre, bananes, haricots.

Edouard et son groupe travail pour augmenter la capacité financière de leur groupe, et valoriser leur business. En fait, le groupe a contracté n prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles pour ravitailler leur business.les bénéfices récoltés après vente de ses produits seront réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour le bon future, un des mebmres est malade ,c'est pourquoi ils sont cinq sur la photo.

Concernant le groupe
Un prêt de groupe signifie que chaque membre prend son montant et l’utiliser pour son propre business, l’avantage est que le groupe garantisse pour les prêts individuels de chaque membre et si un membre ne parvient pas rembourser, tout les membres du groupe remboursent a sa place.
texts.en:
K. Edouard is 32 years old and recently married, so he does not have any children yet. Edouard is the president of the Abadacogora group, which works together to expand their diversified businesses. He works six days a week. Edouard himself sells food products such as potatoes, bananas, and beans. Edouard and his group are working to increase the financial capacity of their group, and to develop their business. In fact, the group has obtained a loan through Amasezerano Community Banking to buy items to resupply their businesses. The profits gained after the sale of these products will be reinvested to maintain the group's financial stability and savings in order to prepare for a successful future. One of the members is sick, which is why only five appear in the photo. Regarding the group: A group loan means that each member takes a certain amount and uses it for his/her own business. The advantage is that the group guarantees the individual loans of its members, and if one member is unable to repay the loan, all the other group members will make up the difference instead.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans. potatoes, maize flour, etc. for retail commerce

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa P. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities. (Photo shows Elsa with her husband, who is her partner in the business.)

In 2010, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and sewing supplies. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and sewing supplies

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ngagne

texts.fr: Monsieur Ngagne S. était un maçon de formation qui travaillait comme ouvrier manoeuvre dans des travaux de construction dans la ville de Mbour . Vu que son travail était trés fatigant pour lui il sollicite ce prêt pour entamer une nouvelle activité qui est le commerce .ainsi avec l'appui de sa femme il compte ouvrir un petit commerce mise à la disposition de femme et les bénéfices serviront à parfaire leur vécu quotidien
texts.en:
Mr. Ngagne S. is a mason by training who worked as a manual labourer for various construction projects in the city of Mbour. Given that his work is very tiring for him, he is seeking this loan to start a new business in the retail sector. Thus, with the support of his wife, he intends to open a store at his wife's disposal, and the profits will be used to provide for their daily needs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn A. is from the village of Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp as well as dried fish, in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Puntabon, Bonbon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Levy

texts.en:
Levy M. is from the village of Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 31 years old, married, and has three children. To make a living, she makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Levy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

location.town: Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Restituta

texts.en:
Restituta D. is from the village of Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro City. She is a 59-year-old widow and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Restituta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

location.town: Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine N., from the village of Nazareth Cagayan de Oro City, is 49 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Engaged in her business for over one year, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie O. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. He is 28 years old and is married. 

Ronie owns a business which provides trisikad (pedicab) services used to transport passengers in the local community. Ronie has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ronie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Ronie from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Noel

texts.en:
Noel L. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. He is 26 years old, married, and has three school-age children. 

Noel owns a business which provides trisikad (pedicab) services used to transport passengers in the local community. Noel has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Noel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noel is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Noel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Need a place to get the latest styles in jean clothing? For friendly service and great help finding something that is just right, stop by Alexander’s little kiosk at the market in Melitopol. He’s been in business for seven years and has an attractive supply of quality, stylish clothes. 

He typically sells about 15,000 UAH worth of clothes each month, earning enough to support himself and his wife who is unable to work. His focus is mainly on jeans jackets, which are very popular, and on men’s pants. Ladies, he may have to refer you to one of his fellow vendors if you don’t find what you’re looking for.
 
Alexander has requested a loan for 10,000 UAH that will enable him add to his inventory and create more choices for his customers. It is important for him to keep a good selection of clothing on hand so he can maintain his competitive edge and continue to earn enough to support his family.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Romy

texts.en: Romy M. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. He is 38 years old. Romy is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Romy operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing trisikad (pedicab) services to local community members. Romy has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Romy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Romy from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline has been operating a hair and beauty salon from home, offering services to passersby and neighbors for the past three years. Her previous occupation was being a school teacher. She is married with two boys; both attend school. Her other source of income comes from her husband's salary.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase a blow dryer and cosmetics and pay for a business license. Caroline hopes to have a big and well equipped beauty parlor in the future. She joined Yehu to acquire a loan and invest in her business.

Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. Caroline rents a house with electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To purchase a blow dryer and comestics and pay for a business permit

loans.name: Kisagazi Farmers, Mubende Group

texts.en:
32-year-old Agiri B. has, for the last ten years, been plying her retail shop business in Kisaagazi, Mubende. With this business, which mostly deals in home utensils like basins, cups, lamps, candles and jerrycans, this married woman has significantly improved her family’s welfare. All her three children are happily in good schools.

Agiri began this business with savings from her farming business. She credits her success to hard work, determination and resilience. Her plan is to turn her retail shop into a wholesale franchise in the near future. In a week, she makes profits that add up to 50,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to purchase more retail items in bulk for her shop so that she does not incessantly run out of stock.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like sugar, basins, salt and bars of soap

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 44 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 3½ and 23 years old. Four of her children currently attend school. She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for 21 years and has employed two people from her community. Her main products are beans, maize, and milk which she sells locally. Her main challenge is too much rain which destroys her crops.

Mary has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will assist her to pay school fees for her children and improve the living standards of the family.

She hopes to improve and expand her business in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Moustapha

texts.fr: Monsieur Moustapha F. est un sociétaire  de 44 ans qui vit dans la localité de Déni  Birame  Ndao dans la communauté  rurale de Bambilor. Il est membre de la caisse depuis janvier 2010. Il est marie et père  de 5 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 3 mois et 8 ans. Il évolue  dans le commerce  de sel et parallèlement  aussi   il pratique l’agriculture basée  sur la culture de persils, piments, etc. Il a choisi ces activités  a cause de leur aspect lucratif. Il sollicite un  crédit de 300 000 frs dans le but de renforcer son activité  de commerce de sel. Ce crédit  pourra lui permettre d’accroitre ses bénéfices et de mieux prendre en charge la dépense  quotidienne et les  autres besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Moustapha F. is 44 years old and lives in the Déni Birame Ndao locality in the rural community of Bambilor. He has been a member of the local group fund since January 2010. He is married and has 5 children, whose ages vary from 3 months to 8 years. He has developed a business selling salt, and at the same time is also involved in farming parsley, peppers, etc. He chose these businesses because of their lucrative nature. He is seeking a loan of 300,000 frs with the goal of strengthening his salt business. This loan will allow him to increase his profits and better provide for his family's needs and daily expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with five children and all her children go to school.   Margaret doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  She owns a bar selling all types of drinks such as beer and local gin.  She  buys crates of beer from delivery vans and local gin from suppliers who get it from villages.  

Margaret wants to  use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin.  She has been in this business for seven years.  Besides this bar business she also owns a restaurant which adds to her income. Her customers are the local people. 

Margaret works seven days a week. Her business challenges include debtors and thieves. She is aspiring of educating her children up to university.  She decided to work with MCDT to get additional capital. Margaret resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema U. is a 61-yearold woman and a mother of five children. She is a tailor by profession and she has been in the tailoring business for the last three years.

She was introduced to Kadet by a Kadet officer and she is now servicing her third loan of Kshs 20,000. She wants the loan to buy more tailoring materials which help her satisfy her customers better in terms of variety.  She hopes to expand the business with the loan.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is 37 years old. He is married with 2 children, ages 1½ and 3 years old. Neither of the children is attending school. He is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. He has been farming for 2 years and has employed one person from the community. His main product is milk which he sells on the local market. He also sells tea leaves and chickens on the local market and owns a posho (cornmeal) mill in the same area. His biggest challenge in farming has been animal diseases and lack of enough animal feed.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 30,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a good dairy cow that will increase his milk production and earn him enough income to cater for the family's expenses.

In future, he would like to improve his dairy farming and make it a real business by improving the quality of the dairy cows and building a modern dairy unit.

He is plans to request more funding in future and hopes for other assistance like training sessions.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He is 42 years old and married with 8 children between the ages of 2½ and 21. Five of the children are currently attending school.

He has been farming for 21 years and has employed 2 people from the community. His main product is milk, which he sells on the local market and the tea estate. He also earns income from his tea which he sells on the local market. His biggest challenge has been lack of qualified artificial insemination services, lack of animal feed, and lack of knowledge of animal diseases.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will increase the family's income through the sale of milk and enable him to repay the loan and meet the family's needs.

In future, he would like to improve his dairy farming by increasing the number of high yielding dairy cows and buying land to plant grass for the dairy cows.

Reuben is grateful to Juhudi for the services provided.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Dama Esha Jefwa

texts.en:
Dama M. is a 51-year-old married mother of four children.  Dama runs a café in Junju in Kilifi, Kenya. She has been in the business for one year. 

Dama was introduced to KADET by a neighbor who is an existing KADET client.  This marks Dama’s first loan from KADET and with this money she hopes to purchase stock of beans, maize and sugar to be used in her cafeteria. Her clients are the residents of Junju.

Dama hopes to improve her living standards from her business.

loans.use: purchase stock of beans, maize and sugar

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 51 years old. He is married with 3 children ages, 8, 10, and 12 years old. All the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 10 years and has 2 employees. His products are maize, milk and tomatoes which he sells on the local market. He also owns some rental houses and a retail shop in the same area.

His major challenges in farming have been the lack of steady markets for his produce and the high cost of labour.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow, after successfully completing a previous loan of 45,000 KES. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will increase his milk production and earn the family enough income.

In future, Peter would like to increase the number of his dairy cows and build more rental houses to increase the family income.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Fenny Kache

texts.en:
Fenny K., 45, is a married mother of three children. Her husband Khamisi Katana is a 53-year-old businessman. Fenny runs a water-selling kiosk in Bamburi, a business that she has operated for five years. Fenny’s side business is poultry farming in the same area and this is also doing well. 

This marks Fenny’s second loan from KADET and with the money she hopes to purchase chick broilers, buy chicken feed, and to connect another water kiosk. She hopes to become a successful businesswoman in future.

loans.use: to purchase chick broilers, buy chicken feed, and connect another water kiosk

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 53 years old. He is married and has 3 children who are all adults. He is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley Kenya. Daniel has been farming for 30 years and has employed 2 people from his community. His main product is milk which he sells to Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Litein town. He depends solely on the income from his farming activities to cater for the family's needs. His biggest challenge in this business has been lack of enough animal feed during the dry season.

Daniel recently completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES and has requested this new loan of 85,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will assist in improving his living standards.

In future, he would like to acquire at least two pure-bred dairy cows and practise zero grazing.

He is grateful to Juhudi for the good work it does.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon T. is a 27-year-old man who is single. He has been operating a retail “kiosk” for last two years in Maweni where he sells items like over-the-counter drugs, soap, cooking oil, biscuits, soft drinks and others.

Simon was introduced to Kadet by a neighbor who knew about Kadet. He is taking his first loan of Kshs 20,000 from Kadet to buy more stock for his business. He hopes to grow his business with the loan and expand to others as well.

loans.use: to buy more stock for his business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 29 years old. She is married with 2 children, ages, 3½ and 5 years old. Both children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Murang'a town in Central Kenya. Esther has been farming for 3 years and has employed one person from her community. Her products are maize, beans and milk which she sells on the local market. She also earns income from her rental houses in the same area. Her biggest challenge in farming has been the unstable market prices for her milk.

Esther has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 52,400 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy a solar lamp. This loan will increase her source of income from the sale of milk and reduce the cost of fuel and save time spent on looking for firewood.

In 5 years' time, she hopes to be producing over 40 litres of milk, up from the current 15 litres and own at least 3 dairy cows, up from the current one.

She says that through Juhudi loans she has been able to realise her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and buy a solar lamp

loans.name: Amy Diagne

texts.fr: Madame Amy Diagne C. est une femme mariée  qui habite dans la localité de Bambilor. Elle est membre de la caisse depuis décembre 2009 et a déjà  bénéficié  d’un prêt antérieur. Elle évolue dans le secteur du commerce et s’active dans l’achat et la vente de poissons fumes, sel, piments et divers condiments utilises par les femmes pour  la cuisine. Elle sollicite un crédit de 50 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat de tamarin et de piment pour renforcer son commerce. Les crédits lui permettent d’accroitre ses revenus et  de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Ms. Amy Diagne C. is a married woman living in the Bambilor locality. She has been a member of the local group fund since December 2009 and has already benefited from one previous loan. She is involved in the business of buying and selling smoked fish, salt, spices, and various condiments used by women to cook. She is seeking a loan of 50,000 frs destined to buy tamarind and spices to strengthen her business. This loan will allow her to increase her income and provide for herself.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Kyunga

texts.en:
Kyunga T. is a 32-year-old single man who runs a motorcycle transport business and a food kiosk. He has been in the business for the past year and he has been making profit of up to Kshs 63,000 per month. His primary business, which is the motorcycle transport, is at the Kilifi stage.

He was introduced to Kadet by a Kadet staff member and he is taking out his first loan of Kshs 80,000 which he is planning to use to purchase iron sheets, buy more stock for the retail stock, and repair his motorbike.  He hopes to expand the size of his business with the loan.

loans.use: purchasing of iron sheets, buy more stock for kiosk, and repair motorbike

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 69 years old and married with 5 children who are all adults. He is a farmer from Murang'a town in Central Kenya where he has been farming for over 30 years. He mainly deals in horticultural produce which he sells to Frigoken Company in Murang'a town. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same area.

His biggest challenge in farming is the unstable prices for horticultural goods, high prices of farm inputs, and lack of enough capital to expand his business.

Peter recently completed his first loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES and has requested this loan for 60,000 KES to purchase dairy goats. The extra income from this loan will enable him to expand his farming activities and improve the family's living standards.

In future, he would like to build more rental houses. He says that through the first loan, he has been able to know how a loan can uplift one's living status.

loans.use: To purchase dairy goats

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
Imad H. is a young man from Bethlehem. He owns an auto repair workshop next to Rachel's Tomb. Imad inherited the workshop from his father. who had it for 40 years. Imad had to change the location of the workshop many times from Rachel's Tomb to another location in the neighboring city of Beit Sahour, and then again  6 months ago to another location next to the Apartheid Wall. Now his workshop is much better.

Due to the many moves, Imad came to FATEN and took a $3,000 to purchase a car jack to replace his old one. This will save Imad time and make it easier to fix a larger number of cars.

In the photo, Imad and one of his six sons are in his workshop.

loans.use: Purchase car jack

loans.name: Gladys Jepsergon

texts.en:
Gladys K. is a 29-year-old resident of Ngolong Village on the outskirts of Kabarnet Town. She is married to Renoes Sergon, 30, and they have been blessed with two children, Hillary (8 )and Kelvin (5).

Gladys runs a kiosk which she started a year ago as her primary source of income. She gets an average profit of Kshs 2500 a month from this business. Her business is located in Ngolong Trading Centre, 10km from Kabarnet Town, and most of her customers are residents of Ngolong and the neighboring villages.

Gladys was introduced to KADET Ltd by a client who had already joined Kadet. She  has taken out a loan of Kshs 5000 from KADET Limited, this being her first loan from any micro-finance institution. She plans to use Kshs 1000 to purchase stationery (exercise books, pens and geometrical sets), kshs 1000 for phone credit cards, and Kshs 3000 to purchase 50kgs of sugar.

Gladys plans to use the profit from the business to expand her business and also educate her children. Her dreams and hopes are to expand her business and give her children the best education possible.

She also hopes that she will be able to support the less fortunate in society, especially in her community. Gladys describes herself has hard-working, humble and a God-fearing lady.

loans.use: To purchase various items for her kiosk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is married with five children, who all attend school. She also takes care of additional family members. Deborah resides in and rents a two room house and the family has access to electricity and no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent.

Deborah owns a stall selling second hand clothes in Ndeeba, Lubaga Division, Kampala district. She buys the second hand clothes from Owino Market, using public transportation to and from the market. She works in Ndeeba market and sells to all categories of people at both retail and wholesale levels. Deborah works six days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She hopes to see her business grow big and to start importing the clothes herself. Deborah joined MCDT because of low interest rates.

loans.use: to buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose R. is married to John Kebut. They are both 45 years old and together they have six children aged between 12 and 23. Rose is a resident of Ngolong Village on the outskirts of the town of Kabarnet. 

Rose runs an agro-vet shop which she started three years ago and is her primary source of income. She makes an average profit of KES 4,000 a month from the business; her other income comes from her spouse’s salary. Rose's business is located in Ngolong Trading Centre on the outskirts of Kabarnet, and most of her customers are residents of Ngolong, the neighboring villages and Pemwai Trading Centre.

Rose was introduced to KADET Limited by a client who had already joined KADET and borrowed KES 15,000 as her second loan. Rose plans to use KES 5,000 to purchase DAP fertilizers, KES 5,000 to purchase hybrid maize seeds and beans, and the remaining KES 5,000 for dairy meals and pesticides. Rose has never before borrowed from any microfinance institution.

Rose plans to use the profit from the business to expand it to maintain her growing clientele as it is the only business of its kind in the centre. Her dreams and hopes are to expand her business and give her children the best education possible. She also hopes that she will be able to support the less fortunate in society, especially in her community.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, maize, bean seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is 47 years old. He is married with 6 children between the ages of 6 and 26. All the children are currently attending school. Raphael is a farmer from Murang'a town in Central Kenya where he has been farming for over 20 years. His main products are maize and beans, which he sells locally. Raphael is also employed as a security guard by one of the country's security firms. His major challenge in farming has been lack of enough capital for expansion.

Raphael has requested this loan for 42,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a good dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sales, thereby increasing his sources of income. He is hoping to excel in this field of business. Raphael says that through Juhudi loans, he will be able to cater to his family's basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Rose Nyaboke

texts.en:
Rose Nyaboke O., 21, is married to Shaliff O. and together they have three children who all attend school. Rose is a businesswoman with a fruit canteen business that she has been running for the last three years on a busy street in the town of Narok.

Rose learned about KADET from other women already registered as clients. This will be her third loan. She is planning to use it to increase her green grocer stock, buy some equipment to assist in fruit processing and open up another fruit shop to meet her customers’ demands. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people.

Rose's future dream is to be able to build her own store and her own house. She also believes she is hardworking and only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: to buy fruit blenders, a fridge, bananas and pinapples and to open up another fruit shop

loans.name: Patrick Mungai

texts.en:
Patrick is a farmer aged 42 years. He is married to one wife and has three children. 

Patrick plants tomatoes and sells the produce within Kiambu to other traders and consumers. He has been in this business for the past seven years. He intends to use the loan he has applied for to buy seeds for planting tomatoes in the next season.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality seeds for tomatoes and pepper

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad S. is a young man from Bethlehem region. He lives with his parents and shares household expenses with his father. Mohammad is a cook at the community center in Bethlehem. Mohammed's father is a taxi driver in the city. Since both have limited incomes, it wasn't easy to buy furniture without taking a $3000 loan from FATEN.

Mohammad tries to save as much as possible from his decent income, but the difficult situation in Bethlehem made it harder for Mohammed to help his father without taking the loan.

In the picture, Mohammed sits in the FATEN office while receiving his loan.

loans.use: Purchase home furniture

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou  F.  est une femme divorcée  ayant en charge 2 enfants dont l’âge  varie entre 20 et 26 ans. Elle est âgée  de 44 ans et a adhéré  à la caisse de Bambilor depuis septembre 2009. Elle évolue  depuis 5 ans dans le secteur du commerce et s’active dans l’achat et la vente d’huile. C’est après  avoir abandonne les études  qu’elle s’est oriente dans ce commerce. Ce qui l’y intéresse c’est son aspect lucratif grâce auquel elle parvient à satisfaire ses besoins vitaux. Le prêt de 300 000 frs qu’elle sollicite sera destine a l’achat de 18 bidons d’huile de 20 litres chacun. L’accroissement  de ses bénéfices  pourra l’aider a gérer  les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou F. is a divorced woman in charge of two children, whose ages range from 20 to 26 years. She is 44 years old and joined the Bambilor group fund in September 2009. She has been involved in the business sector for 5 years and is engaged in buying and selling oil. She started her business after having abandoned her studies. What interests her about business is the income it generates, thanks to which she is able to provide for herself. This loan of 300,000 frs that she is seeking will be used to buy 18 cans of oil, each containing 20 litres. The increase in her profits will help her manage the costs of educating her children.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma is a married man with two girls, aged 8 and 4 years old. His spouse is a housewife and helps with the upbringing of the children and does the house chores. With the 55,000 Kenyan shillings loan, he wants to buy four bull cows for slaughtering to sell on a retail and wholesale basis. Juma also sells milk as his other source of livelihood.

The major challenge in the business is seasonality, as there is a fluctuation of bull-cow supply in the market for meat slaughter. He hopes to open up two other butcher shops someday. His main aim of working with Yehu (a Kiva partner) was to get the financial assistance and help to boost his business and achieve his goals in life. He owns a house and also has rental houses with electricity and piped water. He cites food as his highest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase four bull cows for meat to sell

loans.name: Brisa Del Este. Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del presente comité inició la señora Blanca Oviedo quien contactó  con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona y así conformaron su grupo para trabajar.
 Una de las integrantes es la señora Felicia quien se dedica a la venta de ropas de forma ambulante.
Ella trabaja diariamente a la mañana y la tarde se dedica a la labores de su casa.
Esta actividad le ayuda a ella con los gasto de la alimentación diarias de su familia, y al mismo tiempo le ayuda a su marido quien no posee un ingreso  fijo ya que trabaja como vendedor ambulante en el centro de la ciudad.
Con su crédito ella podrá comprar algunas mercaderías como suéter, pantalones,  jeans ya que actualmente no cuenta con un capital para concretar la compra.
texts.en:
In order to form the present committee, Mrs. Blanca Oviedo got in touch with her friends and neighbors to start a group in their area. One of the group's members is Mrs. Felicia who makes a living selling clothing door-to-door. She works each morning and takes care of the house in the afternoon. This business helps her cover the daily cost of food for her family. It also helps her husband who does not have a regular income and works as an ambulatory salesman in the town's center. She will be able to buy some merchandise like sweaters, pants, and jeans with the loan since she doesn't have the money to buy clothing right now.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sweaters, pants, and jeans.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is married with five children. All of her children go to school. Rosemary also takes care of additional family members. 

She is a tailor on Lubaga Road, making all fashions depending on the customer's needs. She buys clothing materials from Kiyembe, one of the busiest places in Kampala city. She has been in this business for six years. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials. She works from her home, so she doesn’t pay rent for a business premises. Her customers are neighbors and schoolchildren from the nearby school. She works seven days a week. Her  major business challenge is transportation.  

Rosemary joined MCDT, a Kiva partner, because of the low interest rate charged. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house. The family has no access to electricity and no piped water.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materails

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is married with two children; one attends school and the other one is still young. He is a technician by profession, operating his business of selling and repairing electronics in a shop. 

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan, he wants to purchase spare parts for mobile-phone repairs. George has been in the business for the last three years, being a tutor for electronics long before he ventured into cereals sales as his other source of income.

Potential customers are his neighboring community members. He faces the challenge of theft, as he does not have enough security. George hopes to open up a big shop in the future and serve many clients in his town. He owns a home with electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and the electricity bill.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for mobile-phone repairs

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is 31 years old, married with two children. The first born is 4 years old and the younger one is 3. Francois takes care of two dependents in his family. Francois owns a small business selling cow meat in his place of residence. Francois is organised in his business as well as known. The hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

Francois is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing his business through purchasing enough cows for his butcher shop. With this loan Francois will be able to satisfy demand which will allow him to earn more profit.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.es:
Las Sras: Petra que se dedica a la venta de perfumes por catalogo, Margarita Hdez a la venta de artículos para el hogar y ropa,  Micaela a la venta de artículos por catalogo y prendas de oro, Margarita M. y Roberta M. tienen una tiendita de abarrotes y Lina Cortés vende en la cooperativa de la secundaria de su localidad comida y refrescos, ellas  conforman el grupo SAN MIGUEL (FLAT),  todas acordaron en ponerle este nombre por que el día 29 de mayo le festejan a su ángel san miguel arcángel y para ellas es muy importante este día especial en su localidad, san  miguel Atlacahualoya, axochiapan, Morelos.
Esta vez hablaremos de doña Mago como le llaman sus amigas a la señora Margarita Hdez, ella lleva mas de 20 años vendiendo sus artículos para el hogar y ropa para dama y niño (a), tiene 62 años de edad esta casada con el sr. Jesús Gutiérrez, desde hace 46 años, tiene  4 hijos los cuales llevan por nombre: Maria azucena de 33 años (casada), roció de 28 años (casada), cesar de 27 años (soltero), Idalia de 26 años (casada). 

Platica que los créditos le han sido muy útiles para su negocio, y ahora con este crédito quiere surtir mucho mas su negocios y para un futuro necesita levantar un local y condicionarlo para que ahí ella pueda vender, por que donde ella tiene su mercancía es adentro de su casa en la sala y por esta razón le gustaría tener su local.

Ella inicio con el grupo desde hace 4 ciclos a todas las invito la sra. Petra. 
"Petra busco nuevamente a  Fundacion Realidad, para que pudieramos tener la oportunidad de trabajar con sus créditos, ésto es muy bueno para todas, de echo gracias a los créditos recibidos yo he podido ampliar mis negocios que me ayudaron a sacar adelante a todos mis hijos que ahora ya son grandes" comenta Mago.

Todas dan gracias a Fundacion Realidad y a kiva por ser  empresas humanitarias, por confiar en ellas y por la oportunidad, no los defraudaremos.
texts.en:
The women who make up the communal bank "San Miguel" are: Mrs. Petra, who makes a living selling perfume from a catalog, Mrs. Margarita Hdez, who sells home-goods and clothing, Mrs. Micaela, who sells merchandise from catalogs and gold jewelry, Mrs. Margarita M. and Mrs. Roberta M. have a small grocery store, and Mrs. Lin C. sells food and drinks in the local high school. The whole group agreed on the name "San Miguel" because they celebrate the arc-angel Saint Michael on May 29th and this is very special day for them and in their area -- Saint Michael Atlacahualy Axochiapan Morelos. This time we will talk about Mrs. Mago, which is what Margarita Hdez's friends call her. She has been selling home-goods and women's and children's clothing for twenty years. She is sixty-two years old and has been married to Mr. Jesus Gutierrez Idalia for twenty-six years. She tells us that the loans have been very useful for her business and with this loan she wants to really stock her business. At some point in the future, she needs to get a stall and set it up somewhere so she can sell because right now she has her merchandise in the living room of her home (which is why she wants to have her own stall). She joined the group four cycles ago because she was invited by Mrs. Petra (who invited everyone). "Petra looked at Fundacion Realidad so we could have the opportunity to work with their loans; this is very good for everyone. In fact, thanks to the loans I have received, I have been able to grow my businesses which has helped me get all of my children ahead now that they are big," Mago said. Everyone is grateful to Fundacion Realidad and to Kiva for being humanitarian organizations, for trusting in us, and for the opportunity. We will not deceive you.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise, home-goods, and women's and children's clothing.

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.en:
Brigitte was born in 1980 and is married with one child who is 3 years old. She owns a small business selling various products such as: flaskes, plates, cups and so on. She has owned this shop for just two years and employs one person from her community. The hours of her business are from 6 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day.

Brigitte is now requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business. After paying the previous loan, Brigitte wishes to request another one which will be used in her business in order to attract new customers and hopefully earn more profit.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna P. is a 52 year old married woman who supports her family by engaging in food vending. She lives in Habitat Homes, Talisay City, Negros Occidental with her husband and their 3 school aged children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Edna is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she could use it as an additional working capital for food vending. This will be her 19th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Edna aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwainaidi is married with one girl who goes to school. Her spouse is a mechanic by profession and he contributes to the family's needs. She has been selling soft drinks and boiled potatoes for the last year. She sells charcoal as her other source of livelihood.

With the 25,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase a portable cooler box to be used for supplying soft drinks to schoolchildren and neighbors. She also sells at a shop and from home.

Mwanaidi explains that seasonality is her major challenge, as during cold weather there is no demand for soft drinks compared to hot weather. She hopes to operate a retail shop in future. 

With the organization's vision of empowering rural entrepreneurs through accessibility of financial services, she decided to join Yehu to get a loan to improve her living standards. She owns a home  with electricity and piped water. She cites electricity and school fees as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To buy a cooler box to enable her to serve a wider market

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma L. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old. Emma is single. To make a living, Emma runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: El Jardin Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SOLIDARIO SE LLAMA EL JARDIN ESTA UBICADO EN LA COMUNIDAD D. MARCELINO RODRIGUEZ, AXOCHIAPAN, ESTADO D. MORELOS, MEXICO. EL GRUPO ESTA CONFORMADO POR 6 INTEGRANTES QUE SE CONOCEN POR SER VECINOS Y COMERCIANTES.
EL REPRESENTANTE DEL GRUPO SE LLAMA BIBIANA H. H. TIENE 40 AÑOS, ESTUDIO LA SECUNDARIA TERMINADA, TIENE 4 HIJOS, 2 HOMBRES Y 2 MUJERES, ISAIAS TIENE 16 AÑOS, ELIEL 18 AÑOS, JUDITH 20 AÑOS Y GABRIELA 24 AÑOS, ELLA SE DEDICA DESD. HACE 10 AÑOS A LA VENTA D. COMIDA COMO SON TACOS D. ARROZ, SOPES, HAMBURGESAS, HOT DOG, ETC. 
BIBIANA DECIDIO INICIAR EL NEGOCIO EN SU DOMILICIO POR LAS NECESIDADES QUE TENÍA SU FAMILIA, PIUES CON LOS QUE SU ESPOSO GANABA NO LE ALCANZABA Y SUS HIJOS ESTUDIANDO.
AHORA ELLA SOLICITA SU CREDITO PARA COMPRAR CARNE, ACEITE, REFRESCOS, SERVILLETAS Y RECAUDO EN GENERAL.
BINIANA NOS COMENTA "ACTUALMENTE ATIENDO A MAS D. 50 CLIENTES Y MI GRAN SATISFACCION ES QUE LOS CLIENTES ME DICEN QUE MI COMIDA ESTA SABROSA" Y CON ÉSTO ELLA TIENE GANANCIAS LAS CUALES UTILIZA EN SU HOGAR Y TAMBIEN LAS VUELVE A IVERTIR EN LOS INSUMOS PARA SEGUIR EN LA VENTA.
"EN MI COMINIDAD MARCELINO RODRIGUEZ, EL CLIMA ES MUY CALIENTE HAY UNA HACIENDA MUY BONITA Y EL RIO QUE PASA A LA MITAD DEL PUEBLO DEBERÍAN VISITAR ÉSTE LUGAR SEGURO SE LA PASARÁN BIEN Y TODAS NOSOTRAS ESTAMOS AGRADECIDAS CON EL APOYO QUE FRAC NOS HA BRINDADO Y QUE AHORA NOS BRINDA KIVA" NOS DICE BIBIANA 
LOS INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO SON BIBIANA H. H. SE SEDICA A LA VENTA D. COMIDA, REINA M. D. J., COMPRA D. HUERTA D. ELOTES PAR VENDERLO POR BULTO, MARCELA M. P., COMPRA D. ACEITE, AZUCAR, SAL, SOPAS, REFRESCOS, PAPEL HIGIENICO ETC. PARA SURTIR SU TIENDA, MARIA FELIX M. F., VENTA POR CATALOGO, ANA LUISA D. A., VENTA POR CATALO, GREGORIO H. G. VA A SUTIR SU CARNICERIA
texts.en:
The communal bank called "Jardin" is located in the town of Marcelino Rodriguez in the municipality of Axochiapan in the state of Morelos, Mexico. This group is maD. up of 6 members who know each other because they are neighbors and area merchants. Bibiana H. is the representative of the group. She is 40 years old, and finished her secondary education. She has 4 children, 2 boys and 2 girls, they are: Isaias, 16, Eliel, 18, Judith, 20, and Gabriela, 24. For 10 years she has been selling food such as rice tacos, sopes, hamburgers, hot dogs, etc. Bibiana decided to start her business in her home so that she could meet the needs of her family, as her husband's earnings did not cover all the expenses and her children were in school. Now she requests a loan to buy meat, cooking oil, soft drinks, napkins and seasonings. Bibiana tells us that "currently, I attend to more than 50 customers and my greatest satisfaction is that my customers tell me that my food is delicious." With this business she has earnings that she can use for her personal expenses, and she can also use part of the earnings to invest in more supplies to continue the business. Bibiana tells us that, "In my community of Marcelino Rodriguez, the climate is very hot and there is a very pretty plantation and a river that passes through the middle of the town. You should visit this safe place, I know that you will enjoy it. All of us are very grateful for the support that you have provided us, and that now is being provided through Kiva." The members of the group are Bibiana H. H., who sells food, Reina M. D. J., who buys ears of corn from farms and sells them in bulk, Marcela M. P., who will buy cooking oil, sugar, salt, soups, soft drinks, toilet paper, etc. to restock her store, Maria Felix F., who sells through catalogs, Ana Luisa D. A., who sells through a catalog, and Gregorio H. G., who will restock his butcher's shop.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy meat, cooking oil, napkins, soft drinks, tortillas and seasonings

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea was born in 1967 and is a widow with four children aged between 8 and 18. Lea has business selling various products which is interesting in her residence place. Lea is known in the village where she lives which is an advantage for her, because she attracts more customers from various areas. The hours of her business are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day.

Lea has enough experience because this is her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this loan Lea wishes to expand her business through purchasing more products especially foodstuffs. With the extra money Lea will be able to save and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Expanding her businesss

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: Ana B. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old. Ana is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ana runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Ana has been engaged in her business for more than five years. In 2010, Ana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Ana from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pacencia

texts.en:
Pacencia D. is a 49-year old married woman who lives in Barangay Balidbid, Santa Fe, Cebu City. She earns her living by engaging in a dress shop and tailoring business.

Pacencia’s 56 year old husband, Jose, helps his wife with the business and they have 6 children who are between 9-28 years old. Four of the children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. One is already married while the other one is working and helping Pacencia.

Pacencia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a clothes rental business and her tailoring. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Pacencia is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 was used to fund operations of her dress shop and tailoring business and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 13th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 29,500, which she intends to use on her dress shop and tailoring business. Pacencia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sylvain

texts.en:
Sylvain is is 33 years old, married without children. Sylvain works hard in order to get all the necessities for his family. Sylvain owns a business selling various products such as: cosmetics, biscuits, rice, sugar, and so on. This business is profitable in his residence place, and that is the reason why it was chosen by him. Sylvain is a young entrepreneur in this field because he has one year of experience. The hours of his daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day.

Sylvain is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through purchasing more products for his shop. This loan will be used to attract more customers which will be one of the ways of earning more profit.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Rakia

texts.en:
Rakia M. prepares 'waakye' to sell at Abura. She is married to a farmer and has five dependents. She has been educated up to junior high level. Rakia uses the income she makes from the 'waakye' she sells to assist her husband in taking care of the family. Rakia will use the loan to purchase ingredients to prepare 'waakye' for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rakia plans to reinvest back into her business. 

To prepare 'waakye' she gets her beans, rice, and colored leaves from the market. She cooks the beans till they become a little tender, adds the colored leaves to give the beans and the boiling water a wineish colour, then she adds her rice to get a mixture of the rice and beans in the water. She cooks until the mixture becomes tender enough to eat.

'Waakye' is normally eaten with macaroni, 'wele' (cow skin),  'gari' (cassava couscous), salad with pepper sauce, tomato sauce, and fish of any kind and meat of your choice.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to prepare 'waakye'

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
El   Sr. Edgar   está acompañado, el   se dedica a la venta de repuestos para motos, cubierta de auto para  moto  y llantas cuya venta le genera  un buen ingreso.
Con la ayuda de su esposa  están  saliendo adelante con mucho sacrificio y dedicación.
Hoy día el es una microempresario exitoso con  mucha  clientela, debido a su buen trato.
Ha demostrado ser una persona responsable y honesta en sus compromisos, y solicita el préstamo para la compra de cubiertas y respuestas para motos.
texts.en:
Sr. Edgar is married. He is engaged in the sale of spare parts and covers for motorcycles and tires. This business generates a good income. With the help of his wife they are getting ahead with a lot of sacrifice and dedication.

At present, due to his hard work, he is a successful small businessperson with a lot of customers. He has shown himself to be a responsible and honest person who meets his obligations. He is applying for the loan in order to buy covers and spare parts for motorcycles.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of covers and spare parts for motorcycles.

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 39 years old and he is married.  Augustin owns a motorcycle and this motorcycle allows him to earn his family's daily living.  Augustin has been the driver of a motorcycle for about 3 years.

Augustin needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and this loan will allow him to buy one additional motorcycle which will increase his daily profit.
