loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Leoniza

texts.en:
Leoniza D. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 59 years old, widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Leoniza owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Leoniza has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Leoniza joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leoniza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leoniza from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. She also said she likes CEVI's savings system.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment.

loans.name: Mrs. Sangha Nheanh Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank consists of 10 people who live in Svay Ta Ok village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Sangha N. is the village bank president selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Sangha N. is 38 years old. She is a pig breeder who can earn some money from selling pigs to support her family. Now her breeding pig business is good, so she wants to expand. Thus to improve breeding, Mrs. Sangha N. is asking for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding. 

Her husband Mr. Peou Pom is a construction worker. She is the mother of two children who are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben is a farmer from Kisii town, in Western Kenya. He is 41 years old and married with 5 children between the age of 5 and 14. All the children attend school.

Ben has been farming for over 8 years and has employed 3 farmhands. His products are milk, eggs and biogas which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from his employment as an accountant. His major challenge in farming has been lack of capital for expansion and the high cost of poultry feeds.

He recently completed his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000KES and has requested this loan of 70,000KES to expand his poultry project. Through this loan, his family's health will improve and he will be able to earn enough income that will help him educate his children.

In future, Ben would like to produce chickens for sale in large quantities.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth P., 39 years old, is a married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa. She has 3 young children. She is a farmer and has been planting rice for over five years now. She sells her harvest at her town's market. Her husband helps her maintain their farm. She also runs a sari-sari store located at their house. She sells vinegar, sugar, and other daily basic needs her neighbors usually look for. 

Lilibeth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Lilibeth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou  L. is a 39-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in Prk. Kanipa-an, Brgy. Punao, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental.  

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her  business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP6,000. 

Marilou is borrowing PHP 20,000 for more inventory. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Marilou  aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a community member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn L. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 34 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Like most of the people in her town, she also farms for a living. She and her husband till their land for planting rice crops. She sells their harvest in their community. She also started raising pigs. She hopes to acquire piglets that she could raise.

Lovelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lovelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and also feeds for the pigs. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Lovelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure and also feed for the pigs.

loans.name: Mardilyn

texts.en:
Mardilyn S. is 35 and married. She supports her family by operating two business ventures: buying and selling goats and an Avon dealership. She lives in Prk. Lawis-wis Kawayan, Brgy. Bagacay, Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP16,000. 

Mardilyn is now borrowing PHP 29,000 so that she could expand her goat business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Mardilyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a commumnity member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Mrs. Salorn Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twelve villagers in Svay Ta Ok village in Kandal province make up this loan group. Mrs. Salorn P. is its president, selected by the others members who will use portions of their loan for different purposes. She is 40 years old and sells corn to earn money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand so she is applying for a loan to buy more corn to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sophea Yen, is a construction worker. The couple has two children both of whom attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more corn to resell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Margaret has a business selling coffee in Kinoni, which she has had for approximately one year.

To help expand her business, Margaret is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for greater supplies of coffee beans that Margaret will purchase in bulk and resell.  Margaret hopes to generate profit from her business that can support herself and her family in the future.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of coffee.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Twenty-nine year old Marites A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises pigs and then resells them. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 6 years already.

Marites joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Marites is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Marites from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel T. is from the village of  Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 27 years old. Maricel is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Maricel owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Using their motorcycle, Maricel and her husband peddle their fish around the village and nearby places. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maricel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita E., 30, makes sure she meets her family's daily needs. Married to July Tito E., a driver, they have two children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own buy-and-sell business and making native rice cakes to sell for the past few years.

Nenita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues and uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 22,000 loan. This will be used as a source of added capital to buy the raw ingredients necessary to continue production of her rice cakes. She will also invest some of the loan to purchase more products to be incorporated into her buy and sell business inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally furnish her home. She also hopes to have her own stall someday.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: buying raw ingredients for her rice cakes and expanding her buy-and-sell inventory

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr:
Elle est âgée de 45ans, mariée, mère de 5 enfants,le pus âgé a 16ans et le moins âgé a 8ans, les 5 enfants vont à l'école normalement.
Le commerce de fripérie est une affaire de famille,sa grande mère et sa mère le faisait déja, elle aussi a choisit cette activité après leurs morts.
Elle a commencé en 2004 avec un capital de 55000francs, aujourd'hui elle veut s'affirmer, avec le nouveau prêt qu'elle va recevoir, elle voudrait acheter les ballons de premières qualité tel que(les habits non portés , les  serviettes fins de séries et les draps de lit non utilises).
Par jour, elle vend au maximum 60000francs et quand les tenps sont durs, son minimum est de 250000francs.
L'avenir de ses enfants lui  préocupe beaucoup et veut les aider dans leurs réussites en les soutenant moralement et financierement.
Sa vision est  d'ouvrir une boutique qui sera gerer de générations en générations pour  laisser à ses enfants comme héritage.
Son entourage la considère comme une femme battante et pense qu'elle va vraiment réussir.
texts.en:
She is 45 years old and mother to five children, the oldest of whom is 16 years old and the youngest eight years old. The five children attend school normally. The second-hand clothing business is a family business, since her grandmother and her mother did this; she also chose this activity after their deaths. She began in 2004 with a capital of 55,000 francs, and now she would like to assert herself in this business. With the new loan she is going to get, she would like to buy top quality bundles of items, such as unworn clothes, end-of-series towels and unused bedsheets. Her maximum daily turnover is 60,000 francs, and when times are hard, her minimum turnover is 25,000 francs. She is very preoccupied with her children's future and wants to help them succeed by supporting them morally and financially. She has an ambition to open a shop which would be managed from one generation to another and would be left as an inheritance for her children. People close to her consider her to be a fighter and think that she will be really successful.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new bundles of second-hand items: bedsheets, T-shirts, pullovers

loans.name: Mrs. Sobon Naov Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group has twenty people who have selected Mrs. Sobon N. as its leader. They are located in Kaoh Reah Leu village in Kandal province and will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sobon N. was born in 1980. She sells fruit at her local market to earn money to support her family. Since her business in going well she wants to expand so she is seeking a loan to buy more papayas to resell. Her husband, Mr. Sophak Toem, is a farmer who rents a small piece of land to grow crops to sell to support his family. They have two small children.

loans.use: To buy more papayas to resell

loans.name: Erenea

texts.en: Erenea D. P. is a 47-year-old married woman who supports her family by engaging in the selling of frozen products and the buying and selling of used materials (scrap). She lives in San Agustine Madredijos, Cebu City, with her husband and their four children, who are 23 to 29 years old. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her frozen products and used materials businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 3,500 Philippine pesos (Php). Erenea is now borrowing Php 18,000 to use as additional working capital. This will be her 17th loan cycle from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Erenea aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) way. About NWTF In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon . Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -- a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Noeline

texts.en:
Noeline is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has two children. She has a business selling silverfish, which are small dried fish that are very popular in Uganda. Noeline has had her business for approximately two years. Noeline’s business serves the local community by providing an affordable and healthy food source for others in the village.

To help expand her business, Noeline is requesting a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more silverfish stocks which Noeline can then sell at market. Noeline hopes to generate more profit from the expansion of her business and have more financial support for her family.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more silverfish to sell.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Hellen has a retail shop in Kinoni, in which she sells various goods and foodstuffs. To help expand her business, Hellen is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used for buying more stock of goods and expanding the inventory of her retail store. Hellen hopes to save up money earned from her business and be able to support herself financially and have a family in the future. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Buying more goods for retail store

loans.name: Denia

texts.en:
Denia D. is a single woman who lives in Prk. Papaya, Tabao Rizal, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: food vending and a general store. 

Denia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Denia has incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,000. 

This time, for her 6th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000 to buy ingredients for food vending so that she could continue to save up for the future and to expand the business. Denia D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

-------------------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Jamida

texts.en:
N. Jamida is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is young and not yet in school. Jamida has a business selling bananas in bulk in Kinoni. She has had this business for approximately one year. Jamida’s business serves the local community by providing an affordable source of food for many people.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine T. is a single woman who lives in Sitio Quiao, Brgy. Alijis, Valladolid, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by selling gasoline and diesel fuel. 

Josephine  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 7 cycle loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Josephine  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000.  

This time, for her 8th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 16,500 to buy diesel for her business so that she could continue to save up for their future and to financially support her family.  Josephine T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has one child. Harriet has a business selling food goods, particularly bananas, in Kyotera. Despite her young age, Harriet has managed her business for over three years.

To expand her business, Harriet is requesting a loan of 250,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more bananas to resell. Harriet hopes to expand and diversify her business in the future, and help improve the income of her family.

Note to lenders

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.

The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en:
Khaled is a 28-year-old young man from Jenin. He is married and has a one-year old son. Khaled works for the National Palestinian Authority. He was married 3 years ago and is still trying to furnish his house, which is a hard task with the basic salary he receives. Therefore, he took a $1500 loan from FATEN to pay for home furniture.

Khaled's house is very simple and consists of the very basic needs and lacks a lot of of furniture. Khaled is thinking of taking another loan after finishing with the home furniture, and of starting a business as a second source of income, so he can afford a better living standard and secure his wife and son's life.

In the picture, Khaled is leaving FATEN's office.

loans.name: Sulton

texts.en:
Sulton A. is a married man with three adult children. Faced with high unemployment in his country, it proved very hard to find a job and he thus began his own business selling clothes and head-dress. Fortunately, his sales have been good and his business is growing thanks to the quality of his products and the good service he provides. Sulton now needs a loan of 5000 Somoni, which he will use to buy goods to respond to customer demand. He is very thankful to you for helping him to improve his service and his family's quality of life.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

texts.en:
Monique Katinga, 45, is the manager of the Community Bank named “Foi Plus” which means “Faith” in English. It is composed of 20 members united in solidarity to receive Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Monique has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 2005, when she began her business selling used clothing. Her business has prospered thanks to accumulated profit and good management, generating a profit of $40 per week, and her next loan will be used to buy spices in bulk to resell retail with the goal of increasing her profits. Monique’s ambition is to open a general store.

She is a married mother of nine children between the ages 6 and 27, seven of whom attend school.

Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more local juice to sell

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylivia N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has one child. Sylivia has a business running a retail shop, which specializes in selling coffee. Sylivia has had this business for about two years. To expand her business, Sylivia is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda, a Kiva partner. The loan will be used to buy more quantities of coffee that Sylivia can sell to customers in her community. Sylivia hopes to expand her business and possibly sell other products, and gain a greater income for her family. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Buy quantities of coffee to sell

loans.name: Lailikhon

texts.en: Lailikhon D. is 31 years old. For more than eight years, Lailikhon has been running her own business. She has a small salon where she sells and rents traditional wedding dresses and the national wedding dresses. Traditionally, families in Tajikistan are large; consequently, there are lots of marriages and Lailikhon has a lot of clients. The stability of her business allows her to make a considerable contribution to the family’s income. Today, Lailikhon requests 4,000 Somoni, with which she is going to purchase new wedding dresses. Lailikhon would like to assure all deciding to support her that she will pay back the loan on time and is grateful to all of you. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new wedding dresses

loans.name: Doloth

texts.en:
A. Doloth is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka area of Uganda. She is married and has one child. Doloth has a business running a retail shop in Kyotera. Doloth has had this business for about one year. 

To expand her business, Doloth is requesting a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more inventory to sell at her retail shop. Doloth hopes to expand her business, generating greater profit to use for her family.  


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access financing at a young age and to improve their prospects for the future. The loans target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs, and to support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Buy inventory for retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing cattle

loans.name: Mirly

texts.en: Mirly N.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She is 58 years old, married and has three grown-up children. She is from the town of Sta. Josefa. Mirly has been in her business for over 25 years now. Mirly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mirly has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mirly is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be her eighth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. In addition to credit for its clients, CEVI also provides savings, insurance and training through regular cluster group meetings. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Getari Daniel Getari

texts.en: G. D. G. is an entrepreneur – a small business man. He raises poultry, both broilers and layers, in Kitunda Ward in Dar es Salaam. He sells the broilers to customers for meat consumption and eggs for both domestic consumption and business purposes. His business plan is to keep more broilers so he can sell more eggs to meet the demand of the market. His business income is used to meet daily family needs and for business capitalization. D. is requesting a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to capitalize his business

loans.use: To buy more poultry chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
To make a living, Myrna E. plants and harvests rice to sell. She is 39 years old, married and has three school-age children. They live in the town of Sta. Josefa. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years now. Her dream is for her children to finish college and have a bright future. 

Myrna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be her eighth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
H. Firuza is 32 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her husband is an entrepreneur. For more than 6 years, Firuza has been engaged in the business of selling fabrics for national dresses. She gets up at 6 a.m. to prepare breakfast for her husband and children and afterwards, she is busy selling her merchandise until 5 p.m. With this loan, Firuza plans to buy fabrics to increase the range of her selling goods. She is very happy that, thanks to her effort, she has less worry, can help her children with their homework, and is able to make a contribution to her family. Firuza is very grateful for the support that IMON International, with the help of Kiva, provides for her business.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to increase working capital to develop the business

loans.name: Monande

texts.en: Monande M. is an entrepreneur. He runs a business buying and selling eggs to customers in Dar es Salaam city center. He purchases goods direct from poultry keepers wholesale and goes around the city to find customers on a bicycle. He sells 15 to 20 trays of eggs per day. His business income enables him to meet his family's daily needs. He is requesting a loan of 700,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more eggs.

loans.use: To buy more eggs

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy D. is a 28-year old married woman who lives in Gen. Luna St., Labangon Pob. Dalaguete, Cebu City.  She earns her living by operating a bakery business. Her husband, Ronald, 28, who is also a baker and Daisy have three children between the ages of two months and five years old. 

Daisy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 to improve her family's quality of living.  With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 30,000.

Daisy is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 10,000 was used to fund operations of her bakery, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her fourth cycle loan, the amount of Php 15,000 to support her bakery. Daisy is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

---------------------------------
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Racilyn

texts.en:
Racilyn A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 29 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. She is involved in farming and has been planting rice crops for more than seven years already. She gets her income from selling her harvest at the market. She says she works hard so that her family can eat three times a day and her children can go to school. She hopes to see her children graduate from college and have a bright future.

Racilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Racilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farming supplies. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Racilyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farming supplies

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys K. M. is 54 years old. She is widowed and has two children, ages 28 and 19 years old. She describes herself as strict, polite and generous. She sells milk to the local people and schools. Her business is located within a residential area in Kakamega. She has been in this business for the last ten years and has one employee. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is lack of enough feed for the cows leading to low milk production. Nevertheless, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Gladys is using her loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a grade cow that will produce enough milk for her to sell and make more income. In the future, she hopes to be the major supplier of fresh milk in her area.

loans.use: To buy a grade cow

loans.name: Kimchour

texts.en: Mrs. Kimchour C. (in the photo) is 43 years old. She lives in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has two daughters who are waitresses in a restaurant in Phnom Penh City. Her husband is a disabled person. Kimchour has been selling fish in her village for ten years. Her two daughters commute to work in Phnom Penh with their own motorbike, but the motorbike is old and breaks very often. Hence, Kimchour is applying for her first loan in the amount of $500 to buy a new motorcycle for her daughters to replace the old one.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her daughters to drive to work

loans.name: Meshack

texts.en:
Meshack I. I. is 63 years old, widowed and has seven children between the ages of 38 and 28 years old. He describes himself as kind and trustworthy. He has been selling beauty products, including cosmetics, handbags and even shoes. His business is located along the busy Kakamega Webuye highway. He has been doing this business for the last three months now. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is low sales since the business is still new. He is working very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Meshack I. I. is using his loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to boost his current stock of shoes, handbags and cosmetics. He hopes to be a wholesaler of beauty products.

loans.use: To buy handbags, shoes and cosmetics

loans.name: Guiluna

texts.en:
Guiluna P. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Katipunan, Brgy. Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating vegetables vending and food vending businesses.  Her husband Jinky, who works as a Chainsaw helper, also helps his wife.  They have three children who are 16 to 18 years old. 

Guiluna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she wanted something better for her family.  With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Guiluna has been lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000.  

This time, for her 9th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000, which she intends to use to buy vegetables for additional stocks and for future home repairs.  Guiluna P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

---------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital.

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en: Elmira O. is the leader of this group. She is 45. She works in a boarding school in a rural area, and her husband breeds cattle in order to make money. They have two children; both of them study at school. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 16,000 soms ($347.82), Elmira and her husband bought a cow and since that time her husband has been breeding cattle. Elmira and her husband make 4,800 soms ($104.34) per month selling milk every day, and sometimes cattle when it is necessary. With money received from this loan, Elmira wants to purchase a cow to increase their number of cattle. Ainur R. is the treasurer of the group. She is 41 and a widow. She has raised four children: three sons and a daughter. The sons study at school but the daughter has not started yet. Ainur works as a teacher at school. She also has a part-time job in a pharmacy. A few years ago, Ainur started to breed cattle and now she wants to get a loan to purchase a bull calf to sell after fattening it, to make some money. Burulkan O., age 59, is a widow. She is retired and receives a monthly pension of 7,100 soms ($154.34). She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase kitchen furniture in order to improve her living conditions. Kulbubu B., age 43, is married. She works as a librarian and her husband is a bus driver. They have three children; all of them are students. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms ($434.78) Kulbubu bought a cow and since that time she has been breeding cattle. That cow gives 12 liters of milk daily. By selling that milk, Kulbubu makes 4,800 soms ($104.34) per month. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase a bull calf in order to sell it after fattening it, to make some money. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Masinadyahon, Brgy. Maquiling, Sagay City, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living as a coconut grinder and repair & maintenance shop owner.  Her husband Erasmo, who is 70 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  He also helps his wife.  They have eight children who are 27 to 37 years old. 

Erlinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1989 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500.  

This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 to buy welding rods and other stock for her shop so she could continue to save up for future home repairs and education.  Erlinda B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato E. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 55 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. He is a farmer. He has been tilling his rice field for over 22 years now. He also raises pigs. Like other fathers, he only wants the best for his family. 

Renato joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Renato has successfully repaid his previous loans from CEVI. Renato is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP, which he will use to purchase fertilizer for his field and feed for the pigs. This is his eighth loan from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more videos  and some furniture

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a divorced mother of four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of her sisters children. 

Annet owns a bar in Mengo Mackay where she sells all types of drinks such as beer and local gin. She has been in this business for over five years. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and jerycans of the local gin  Annet sells on retail basis only. She sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include thieves and defaulters. 

Annet is aspiring to build a house for her family. She rents a two-roomed house where her family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her major monthly expenses are food, rent, and school fees. She joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her capital base.

loans.use: To buy beer and gin

loans.name: Scholastica Atieno

texts.en:
Scholastica Atieno O. is 32 years old and is married to Jashon Check. They have four children (Michael, 14; Vinn, 11;  Edna, 7; and Clear Atieno, 2). They live in the Skyway area of Kisumu city. Her husband Jashon is an electrician and does his work within town and contributes to the wellbeing of his family.

Scholastica is a tailor and has been in this business for the past 12 years, thanks to her mother who taught her the skills when she was a young girl. Scholastica has been a client of KADET Ltd for sometime now. She is applying for her sixth loan, after successfully repaying the previous ones. She intends to use the money to buy materials to add to her stock which will enable her meet the demands of her clients by being able to design for them nice outfits.

Her dreams are to become the leading tailor in her neighborhood and to educate all her children to the university level.

loans.use: Buy materials for her business

loans.name: Asomuddin

texts.en:
K. Asomuddin is 33 years old, married, and has four children. He is a very enterprising person. Thirteen years ago he began to work with inoculated animals and go door-to-door in the city selling the meat. At that time, he didn't own a space for a butcher shop. After getting married, he and his wife decided to open a grocery store and butcher shop. Today, Asomuddin is in charge of the butcher shop, and his wife runs the grocery store. To expand their business, Asomuddin requests a loan to buy some animals for their butcher shop and foodstuff for their grocery store.

loans.name: Romy

texts.en:
Romy D. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 33 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Romy raises rice for sale. Romy has been engaged in his business for over 15 years.

Romy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Romy is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds and to pay for the laborers who help at the farm. loans.name: Stephen Otieno

texts.en:
Stephen Otieno M. is a 26-year-old man from Obunga in Kisumu city. He is married to Mercy Achieng and they have two children — Violet Atieno, four years old and in kindergarten, and baby Grace Auma.

Stephen has a motorcycle that he uses to transport people from one point to the other within Kisumu city. He is applying for his first loan from Kadet Ltd to enable him buy spare parts to fix his motorcyle and also to open a spare-parts shop.

His dream is to grow in the transportation business and use the profits for the well-being of his family.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for his motorcycle

loans.name: Burulbu's Group

texts.ru:
Человеческая судьба неповторима и настолько своеобразна, что можно бесконечно поражаться всем неизведанным поворотам, и неожиданным изменениям в жизни, которые заставляют нас принимать ответственные решения и тем самым помогают нам держаться в тонусе. Эти стихийные события и делают нас сильными, укрепляют нашу веру в себя и не дают нам расслабиться. Герои этой истории – люди, которые в самый пик безработицы, экономического спада, и политической нестабильности, целеустремлённо продолжают заниматься своим делом, и шаг за шагом претворяют свои мечты в действительность. Тагайматова Бурулбу – лидер группы. Бурулбу пятьдесят семь лет. Когда в стране повсеместно царила безработица и люди от безысходности начали покидать страну в поисках заработка, Бурулбу предпочла использовать средства, которые у неё имелись, для того, чтобы остаться на плаву. Она ещё с детства знакома с животноводством и решила, что это и есть её формула успеха. Теперь она разводит скот и продаёт молоко. Продажа молока приносит две тысячи восемьсот сомов ежемесячно. У Бурулбу пятеро детей и нехватку в помощи ей не пришлось ощущать. Благодаря совместным усилиям всей семьи, был построен дом. Далее Бурулбу благополучно женила сына. Не все члены вовлечены в животноводство. Разведением скота занимается Бурулбу и её младший сын. Муж Бурулбу работает охранником на стоянке, но в свободное время активно помогает Бурулбу по хозяйству. Один из сыновей работает на сахарном заводе, а две дочери уехали на заработки в Россию. Младший сын работает в водном хозяйстве, и помогает маме ухаживать за скотом.  Бурулбу обратилась за кредитом, так как давно мечтала купить стиральную машину, которая облегчила бы её домашние хлопоты. 

Партнёры Бурулбу по группе:

Суранчиевой Жайнагуль двадцать пять лет. Вместе с мужем Жайнагуль занимается разведением скота и продажей молока. У Жайнагуль одна четырёхлетняя дочь. Жайнагуль надеется получить этот кредит, чтобы купить холодильник, и тогда её молоко не будет пропадать. 

Турдугуловой Атыркуль пятьдесят три года. Она – вдова и мать троих детей и уже воспитывает внуков. Тем не менее, Атыркуль до сих пор занимается животноводством. Она обратилась за кредитом, с целью купить ткани для приготовления приданого дочери.

Алыбаевой Чолпон пятьдесят лет. Чолпон – вдова и мать четверых детей. Она вместе с одним сыном занимается разведением скота. Чолпон намерена использовать кредит для подготовки приданого дочери.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
The human destiny is so unique and original that one can be endlessly amazed at all the uncharted turns and unexpected changes in life that compel us to make responsible decisions and keep us alert. These spontaneous events make us strong, strengthen our belief in ourselves and keep us from becoming lazy. The heroes of this story are people who at the peak of unemployment, economic recession and political instability resolutely continue to do their work and step by step realize their dreams. Burulbu T. is the leader of this group. Burulbu is 57 years old. As the country was suffering from unemployment and hopeless people began to leave the country in search of work, Burulbu preferred to use the funds that she had in order to stay afloat. She has been familiar with livestock husbandry since childhood and decided that this would be her formula for success. Now she breeds cattle and sells milk. The sale of milk brings 2,800 som per month. Burulbu has five children and she never felt a lack of help. Through the joint efforts of the entire family, they built a house. Next, Burulbu successfully married her son. Not all members of the family work with the animals. Burulbu and her youngest son are involved in breeding cattle. Burulbu’s husband works as a security guard at a parking lot; but in his spare time actively helps Burulbu with her work. One of her sons works at a sugar factory, while her two daughters have gone to work in Russia. The youngest son works in water management and helps his mother tend to the animals. Burulbu is requesting the loan to buy a washing machine, which has been her dream for a long time as it would lighten the load of her household chores. Burulbu’s partners in the group: Zhayangul S. is 25 years old. Together with her husband Zhayangul works in animal breeding and sells milk. She has a 4 year old daughter. Zhayangul hopes to get this loan to buy a refrigerator, so her milk will not spoil. Artykul T. is 53 years old. She is a widow and the mother of three children, and she is raising her grandchildren. Nevertheless, Artykul still works in animal husbandry. She is requesting the loan to buy fabric to make a dowry for her daughter. Cholpon A. is 50 years old. She is a widow and mother of four children. Together with her son she is engaged in breeding cattle. Cholpon plans to use the loan to prepare a dowry for her daughter.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase a washing machine

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.en:
M. Ilhomjon is married. His wife is a homemaker and they have two children. He has always been a hard worker, someone who started at an early age helping his mother with her clothing business and contributing his earnings to the family from the time he was young. When Ilhomjon married, his expenses increased and he had to strike out on his own to build a business that would support his own family. With the help of his father, he started a clothing-sales business and his wife helped him. His business has grown and he wants to continue to grow in order to improve his quality of life. He is asking for a loan of 7500 Somoni to buy more merchandise for his business. Ilhomjon and his family are very grateful for the support you are providing to help them get ahead.  
   
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Buying new clothing to sell

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 34 years old. Rosalyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalyn raises crops. The main source of income for her business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rosalyn has been engaged in her business for more than 17 years. Rosalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rosalyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and other farm inputs. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Rosalyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nicholas Gedion

texts.en:
Nicholas Gedion O. is a 22-year-old single man from the Nyalenda area in Kisumu, Kenya.  He is a new client in Kadet Ltd and this is his first loan.

Nicholas is an electrician and intends to use the money from this loan to buy more electronic spare parts to add to his stock. Most of his clients consist of constructors who buy spare parts from him during the construction process.

His desire is to see his business grow and to be able to create job opportunities by employing someone to help him with the shop.

loans.use: Buy electronics to add to his shop

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia R. is an entrepreneur and a married woman.  She runs a business selling traditional clothes (Vitenge ang Khanga) at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. She purchases goods from wholesale and retail shops in the Mnazi Mmoja business shopping center and sells them to retail customers.

Her business plan is to open more shops as her business income grows. She is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mairamo

texts.en:
Mairamo is an enterprising woman with a big desire to improve the quality of life of her family. She is married and the mother of four children. Mairamo has been a seamstress since she was very young. With a lot of effort, she has been able to open a small shop in her home and has been successful because her customers have recognized the high quality of her products. In this way, she constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. 


Today Mairamo is applying for a loan from IMON International for the second time. She is requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni to purchase new modern fabrics for sewing national dresses. You can help improve the quality of life of her family. Mairamo and her children are grateful for your generosity and support.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for sewing national dresses.

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en: Ruben M. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 45 years old. Ruben is single. To make a living, Ruben raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ruben has been engaged in his business for over 15 years. Ruben joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruben has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ruben is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and gas for the tractor he used. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Ruben from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it. About CEVI Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
